''Traditional Folk Remedies'' (Century, 1987) p.155</ref> | [[File:Alcea rosea purple.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Alisma plantago-aquatica]]'' | Water-plantain | Used for the urinary tract.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-347-WATER+PLANTAIN.aspx?activeIngredientId=347&activeIngredientName=WATER+PLANTAIN&source=3 |title = Water Plantain |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425123040/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-347-WATER+PLANTAIN.aspx?activeIngredientId=347&activeIngredientName=WATER+PLANTAIN&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Alisma plantago-aquatica20090812 251.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Allium sativum]]'' | [[Garlic]] | Widely used as an [[antibiotic]]<ref>{{cite journal |url = http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/journals/mdd/v05/i04/html/04news4.html |title = Garlic: a natural antibiotic |author = Nicole Johnston |journal = Modern Drug Discovery |date = April 2002 |volume = 5 |issue = 4 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070817142551/http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/journals/mdd/v05/i04/html/04news4.html |archivedate = 2007-08-17 |df = }}</ref><ref name="cai2007"> {{cite journal |pages=335–8 |doi=10.1038/ja.2007.45 |title=Antibacterial Activity of Allicin Alone and in Combination with β-Lactams against Staphylococcus spp. And Pseudomonas aeruginosa |year=2007 |last1=Cai |first1=Yun |last2=Wang |first2=Rui |last3=Pei |first3=Fei |last4=Liang |first4=Bei-Bei |journal=The Journal of Antibiotics |volume=60 |issue=5 |pmid=17551215}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |pmid=17539285 |year=2007 |last1=Eja |first1=ME |last2=Asikong |first2=BE |last3=Abriba |first3=C |last4=Arikpo |first4=GE |last5=Anwan |first5=EE |last6=Enyi-Idoh |first6=KH |title=A comparative assessment of the antimicrobial effects of garlic (Allium sativum) and antibiotics on diarrheagenic organisms |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=343–8 |journal=The Southeast Asian Journal of Tropical Medicine and Public Health}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |pmid=17370439 |year=2006 |last1=Tessema |first1=B |last2=Mulu |first2=A |last3=Kassu |first3=A |last4=Yismaw |first4=G |title=An in vitro assessment of the antibacterial effect of garlic (Allium sativum) on bacterial isolates from wound infections |volume=44 |issue=4 |pages=385–9 |journal=Ethiopian Medical Journal}}</ref> and, more recently, for treating [[cardiovascular disease]]<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=16484553 |year=2006 |last1=Rahman |first1=K |last2=Lowe |first2=GM |title=Garlic and cardiovascular disease: A critical review |volume=136 |issue=3 D. |last2=Lawson |first2=L. D. |last3=Block |first3=E. |last4=Chatterjee |first4=L. M. |last5=Kiazand |first5=A. |last6=Balise |first6=R. R. |last7=Kraemer |first7=H. C. |journal=Archives of Internal Medicine |volume=167 |issue=4 |pmid=17325296}}</ref> Garlic is a [[monoamine oxidase inhibitor]] and has antidepressant-like effects on mice<ref>{{cite journal |pmc=2792615|year=2008|author1=Dhingra|first1=D|title=Evidences for the involvement of monoaminergic and GABAergic systems in antidepressant-like activity of garlic extract in mice|journal=Indian Journal of Pharmacology|volume=40|issue=4|pages=175–179|last2=Kumar|first2=V|doi=10.4103/0253-7613.43165|pmid=20040952}}</ref> so might be used as a herbal antidepressant or [[anxiolytic]] in humans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mirecc.va.gov/visn4/BHL/docs/Herbal_Remedies_and_Nutritional_Supplements.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222211026/http://www.mirecc.va.gov/visn4/BHL/docs/Herbal_Remedies_and_Nutritional_Supplements.pdf |archivedate=2016-12-22 |df= }}</ref> | [[File:GarlicBasket.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Aloe vera]]'' | [[Aloe vera]] | Leaves are widely used to [[Aloe vera#Claims of medical properties|heal burns]], [[wound]]s and other [[skin disease|skin ailments]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tamilnadu.com/herbs/kathalai.html|title=Kathalai|publisher=Tamilnadu.com|date=7 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411215153/http://tamilnadu.com/herbs/kathalai.html|archivedate=11 April 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/aloevera/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Aloe Vera |accessdate = 2011-09-29 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150128182411/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/aloevera |archivedate = 2015-01-28 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Aloe Vera.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Althaea officinalis]]'' | [[Marsh-mallow]] | Used for over 2,000 years as both a food and a medicine<ref name="haubrich" /> | [[File:Althaea officinalis Prague 2011 2.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Amorphophallus konjac]]'' | [[Konjac]] | Significant dietary source of [[glucomannan]],<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=9109608 |year=1997 |last1=Baer |first1=DJ |last2=Rumpler |first2=WV |last3=Miles |first3=CW |last4=Fahey Jr |first4=GC |title=Dietary fiber decreases the metabolizable energy content and nutrient digestibility of mixed diets fed to humans |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=579–86 |journal=The Journal of Nutrition}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=10372241 |year=1999 |last1=Vuksan |first1=V |last2=Jenkins |first2=DJ |last3=Spadafora |first3=P |last4=Sievenpiper |first4=JL |last5=Owen |first5=R |last6=Vidgen |first6=E |last7=Brighenti |first7=F |last8=Josse |first8=R |last9=Leiter |first9=LA |last10=Bruce-Thompson |first10=C |title=Konjac-mannan (glucomannan) improves glycemia and other associated risk factors for coronary heart disease in type 2 diabetes. A randomized controlled metabolic trial |volume=22 |issue=6 |pages=913–9 |journal=Diabetes Care|display-authors=8 |doi=10.2337/diacare.22.6.913}}</ref> which is used in treating [[obesity]],<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=16320857 |year=2005 |last1=Keithley |first1=J |last2=Swanson |first2=B |title=Glucomannan and obesity: A critical review |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=30–4 |journal=Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine}}</ref> [[constipation]],<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=2547312 |year=1989 |last1=Marzio |first1=L |last2=Del Bianco |first2=R |last3=Donne |first3=MD |last4=Pieramico |first4=O |last5=Cuccurullo |first5=F |title=Mouth-to-cecum transit time in patients affected by chronic constipation: Effect of glucomannan |volume=84 |issue=8 |pages=888–91 |journal=The American Journal of Gastroenterology}}</ref> and reducing cholesterol.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12569112 |year=2003 |last1=Chen |first1=HL |last2=Sheu |first2=WH |last3=Tai |first3=TS |last4=Liaw |first4=YP |last5=Chen |first5=YC |title=Konjac supplement alleviated hypercholesterolemia and hyperglycemia in type 2 diabetic subjects—a randomized double-blind trial |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=36–42 |journal=Journal of the American College of Nutrition |doi=10.1080/07315724.2003.10719273}}</ref> | [[File:Amorphophallus_konjac_(fruit)_01.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Anemone hepatica]]'' | Common hepatica | Historically used to treat liver diseases, it is still used in alternative medicine today. Other modern applications by herbalists include treatments for [[pimple]]s, [[bronchitis]] and [[gout]].<ref>Howard, Michael. ''Traditional Folk Remedies'' (Century, 1987); p.161–2</ref> | [[File:Common Hepatica - Anemone hepatica (13214136064).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Angelica archangelica]]'' | Garden angelica | Roots have been used in the traditional Austrian medicine internally as tea or tincture for treatment of disorders of the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, nervous system, and also against fever, infections, and flu.<ref>{{ cite journal | vauthors =Vogl S, Picker P, Mihaly-Bison J, Fakhrudin N, Atanasov AG, Heiss EH, Wawrosch C, Reznicek G, Dirsch VM, Saukel J, Kopp B| title =Ethnopharmacological in vitro studies on Austria's folk medicine - An unexplored lore in vitro anti-inflammatory activities of 71 Austrian traditional herbal drugs| journal =J Ethnopharmacol| doi=10.1016/j.jep.2013.06.007| pmid=23770053 | volume=149 | issue=3 | pages=750–71 | pmc=3791396 | year=2013}}</ref> | [[File:Coulon-Angélique.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Angelica sinensis]]'' | [[Dong quai]] | Used for thousands of years in Asia, primarily in women's health.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = Mayo Clinic |title = Dong quai (Angelica sinensis [Oliv.] Diels) |url = http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/dong-quai/NS_patient-Dongquai |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111006232934/http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/dong-quai/NS_patient-dongquai |archivedate = 2011-10-06 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Apium graveolens]]'' | [[Celery]] | Seed is used only occasionally in tradition medicine. Modern usage is primarily as a [[diuretic]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7PRyMWo5e28C&lpg=PP1&dq=Herbal%20Drugs%20and%20Phytopharmaceuticals&pg=PA52#v=onepage&q&f=false | publisher=CRC Press | work=Herbal drugs and phytopharmaceuticals | accessdate=2011-10-18 | title=Apii Fructus | page=52 | author=Max Wichtl | isbn=0-8493-1961-7 }}</ref> | [[File:Apium graveolens 002.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Arctium lappa]]'' | [[Burdock]] | Used traditionally as a [[diuretic]] and to lower blood sugar<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.mskcc.org/mskcc/html/69154.cfm |title = Burdock |publisher = Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111029102328/http://www.mskcc.org/mskcc/html/69154.cfm |archivedate = 2011-10-29 |df = }}</ref> and, in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] as a treatment for sore throat and symptoms of the common cold.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = Naturopathy Digest |title = Burdock (niu bang zi) |work = Herbs & Botanical |url = http://www.naturopathydigest.com/nutrition_herbs/herbs/burdock.php |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120425080121/http://www.naturopathydigest.com/nutrition_herbs/herbs/burdock.php |archivedate = 2012-04-25 |df = }}{{unreliable source?|date=October 2011}}</ref> | [[File:ArctiumLappa4.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Arnica montana]]'' | [[Arnica montana|Arnica]] | Used as an [[anti-inflammatory]]<ref>{{cite journal |pages=130–6 |doi=10.1159/000093790 |title=Anti-Inflammatory Activity of Thymol: Inhibitory Effect on the Release of Human Neutrophil Elastase |year=2006 |last1=Braga |first1=Pier Carlo |last2=Dal Sasso |first2=Monica |last3=Culici |first3=Maria |last4=Bianchi |first4=Tiziana |last5=Bordoni |first5=Luca |last6=Marabini |first6=Laura |journal=Pharmacology |volume=77 |issue=3 |pmid=16763380}}</ref> and for osteoarthritis.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=585–91 |doi=10.1007/s00296-007-0304-y |title=Choosing between NSAID and arnica for topical treatment of hand osteoarthritis in a randomised, double-blind study |year=2007 |last1=Widrig |first1=Reto |last2=Suter |first2=Andy |last3=Saller |first3=Reinhard |last4=Melzer |first4=Jörg |journal=Rheumatology International |volume=27 |issue=6 |pmid=17318618}}</ref> The US Food and Drug Administration has classified ''Arnica montana'' as an unsafe herb because of its toxicity.<ref name="drugs.com">{{Cite web | url = https://www.drugs.com/npp/arnica.html | publisher = [[drugs.com]] | title = Arnica | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170108094251/https://www.drugs.com/npp/arnica.html | archivedate = 2017-01-08 | df = }}</ref> It should not be taken orally or applied to broken skin where absorption can occur.<ref name="drugs.com"/> | [[File:Arnica montana (flower head).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Astragalus propinquus]]'' | [[Astragalus]] | Long been used in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] to strengthen the [[immune system]], and is used in modern China to treat [[hepatitis]] and as an adjunctive therapy in [[cancer]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/astragalus/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Astragalus |accessdate = 2011-09-29 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150213010943/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/astragalus |archivedate = 2015-02-13 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Astragalus_membranaceus.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Atropa belladonna]]'' | Belladonna | Although toxic, was used historically in [[Italy]] by women to enlarge their pupils, as well as a [[sedative]], among other uses. The name itself means "beautiful woman" in Italian.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/531.html |publisher = [[National Institute of Health]] [[MedlinePlus]] |title = Belladonna |accessdate = 2011-10-01 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111001164138/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/531.html |archivedate = 2011-10-01 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Flickr - don macauley - Deadly Nightshade.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Azadirachta indica]]'' | [[Neem]] | Used in India to treat worms, [[malaria]], [[rheumatism]] and [[skin infection]]s among many other things. Its many uses have led to neem being called "the village dispensary" in India.<ref>{{cite journal |title = Neem: A therapeutic for all seasons |author = S. Ganguli |journal = Current Science |volume = 82 |issue = 11 |date = June 10, 2002 |url = http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/jun102002/1303.pdf |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605054940/http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/jun102002/1303.pdf |archivedate = June 5, 2011 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Tender_Neem_leaves_in_Karnataka,_India.JPG|200x200px]]
|}

|- | ''[[Berberis vulgaris]]'' | [[Barberry]] | Long history of medicinal use, dating back to the [[Middle Ages]] particularly among [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s. Uses have included [[skin disease|skin ailments]], [[scurvy]] and [[GI tract|gastro-intestinal ailments]].<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.drugs.com/npp/barberry.html |title = Barberry |publisher = Drugs.com |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120620145827/http://www.drugs.com/npp/barberry.html |archivedate = 2012-06-20 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Berberis_thunb_frt.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Borago officinalis]]'' | [[Borage]] | Used in [[hyperactive]] [[gastrointestinal]], [[respiratory]] and [[cardiovascular]] disorders,<ref>{{cite journal | author = Gilani A.H., Bashir S., Khan A.-U. | year = 2007 | title = Pharmacological basis for the use of Borago officinalis in gastrointestinal, respiratory and cardiovascular disorders | url = | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 114 | issue = 3| pages = 393–399 | doi=10.1016/j.jep.2007.08.032}}</ref> such as gastrointestinal ([[colic]], [[cramps]], [[diarrhea]]), airways ([[asthma]], [[bronchitis]]), cardiovascular, ([[cardiotonic]], [[antihypertensive]] and blood purifier), [[urinary]] (diuretic and kidney/bladder disorders).<ref>Gilani A.H. "Focused Conference Group: P16 - Natural products: Past and future? Pharmacological use of borago officinalis", ''Basic and Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology''. Conference: 16th World Congress of Basic and Clinical Pharmacology. WorldPharma 2010 Copenhagen Denmark. Publication: (var. pagings). 107 (pp 301), 2010. Date of Publication: July 2010.</ref> | [[File:Borage starflower Rohtopurasruoho 02.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Broussonetia kurzii]]'' | Salae | Known as ''Salae'' in Thailand where this species is valued as a [[medicinal plant]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsbg.org/database/plantdb/mdp/medicinal-specimen.asp?id=671|title=qsbgplant-db|author=|date=|website=QSBG Database|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202053551/http://www.qsbg.org/database/plantdb/mdp/medicinal-specimen.asp?id=671|archivedate=2017-02-02|df=}}</ref> | |}
== C ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Calendula officinalis]]'' | [[Calendula officinalis|Marigold]] | Also named calendula, has a long history of use in treating wounds and soothing skin<ref>{{cite web |url = http://medicinalherbinfo.org/herbs/Calendula.html |title = Calendula: Herbal Remedies |publisher = Discovery Fit & Health |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120425080213/http://medicinalherbinfo.org/herbs/Calendula.html |archivedate = 2012-04-25 |df = }}{{Self-published inline|date=October 2011}}</ref> | [[File:2006-10-22Calendula03.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Capsicum annuum]]'' | [[Cayenne pepper|Cayenne]] | Type of [[capsicum|chili]] that has been used as both food and medicine for thousands of years. Uses have included reducing pain and swelling, lowering [[triglyceride]] and [[cholesterol]] levels and fighting viruses and harmful bacteria, due to high levels of [[Vitamin C]].<ref>{{cite journal |url = http://www.theanalystmagazine.com/pr/1302.htm |journal = The Analyst Magazine |title = Ancient Americans liked it hot – Smithsonian study traces Mexican cuisine roots to 1,500 years ago |author = Randall Kremer |year = 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120425080132/http://www.theanalystmagazine.com/pr/1302.htm |archivedate = 2012-04-25 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://medplant.nmsu.edu/capsicum.shtm |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080515111829/http://medplant.nmsu.edu/capsicum.shtm |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2008-05-15 |work = Medicinal Plants of the Southwest |title = Capsicum spp. |first1 = Yvonne |last1 = Tso |first2 = Bridgette |last2 = Love |first3 = Rocio Cisneros |last3 = Ibañez |first4 = Jamie |last4 = Ross }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=The Health Benefits of Cayenne | first1=John | last1=Heinerman | publisher=McGraw-Hill | year=1999 | isbn=0879837039 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QcmzL4KTCQ0C&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3jvJU7_3HdbesAS4x4LIDQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA }}</ref> | [[File:Capsicum_annuum_10_-_Kew.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Capsicum frutescens]]'' | [[Capsicum|Chili]] | Its active ingredient, [[capsaicine]], is the basic of commercial pain-relief ointments in Western medicine. The low incidence of [[heart attack]] in Thais may be related to capsaicine's [[Fibrinolysis|fibronolytic action]] (dissolving blood clots).<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=American Journal of Clinical Nutrition |author1=Sukon Visudhiphan |author2=Sittith Poolsuppasit |author3=Orachun Piboonnukarintr |author4=Samorn Tumliang | volume=35 | issue=6 | date=June 1982 | pages= 1452–1458 | title=The relationship between high fibrinolytic activity and daily capsicum ingestion in Thais | pmid=7081126 | postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref> | [[File:Tabasco peppers.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Carica papaya]]'' | [[Papaya]] | Used for treating wounds and stomach troubles. <ref>{{cite journal |pmid=19041705 |year=2009 |last1=Gurung |first1=S |last2=Skalko-Basnet |first2=N |title=Wound healing properties of Carica papaya latex: In vivo evaluation in mice burn model |volume=121 |issue=2 |pages=338–41 |doi=10.1016/j.jep.2008.10.030 |journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology}}</ref> | [[File:Carica papaya 005.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cassia occidentalis]]'' | [[Coffee senna]] | Used in a wide variety of roles in traditional medicine, including in particular as a broad-spectrum internal and external antimicrobial, for liver disorders, for intestinal worms and other parasites and as an immune-system stimulant.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.fs.fed.us/global/iitf/pdf/shrubs/Senna%20occidentalis.pdf |title = Senna occidentalis (L.) Link |author = John K. Francis |publisher = International Institute of Tropical Forestry |accessdate = 2011-10-17 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101122121430/http://www.fs.fed.us/global/iitf/pdf/shrubs/Senna%20occidentalis.pdf |archivedate = 2010-11-22 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://rain-tree.com/fedegosa.htm |title = Tropical Plant Database |publisher = Raintree Nutrition |accessdate = 2011-10-17 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111027175150/http://www.rain-tree.com/fedegosa.htm |archivedate = 2011-10-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Senna occidentalis.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Catha edulis]]'' | [[Khat]] | Mild stimulant used for thousands of years in Yemen, and is banned today in many countries. Contains the [[amphetamine]]-like substance [[cathinone]]. | [[File:Catha edulis.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cayaponia espelina]]'' | São Caetano melon | It is a [[diuretic]] and aid in the treatment of [[diarrhea]] and [[syphilis]].<ref name="johnsont">{{cite book|last=Johnson|first=Timothy|title=CRC Ethnobotany Desk Reference|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|year=1999|page=178|isbn=0-8493-1187-X}}</ref> | [[File:Cayaponia espelina fruit.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Centaurea cyanus]]'' | Cornflower | In [[herbalism]], a [[decoction]] of cornflower is effective in treating [[conjunctivitis]] and as a wash for tired eyes.<ref name=Century>{{cite book |last=Howard |first=Michael |title=Traditional Folk Remedies |publisher=Century |date=1987 }}</ref> | [[File:CentaureaCyanus-bloem-kl.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Chrysopogon zizanioides]]'' | Vetiver | Used for skin care.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-695-VETIVER.aspx?activeIngredientId=695&activeIngredientName=VETIVER&source=3 |publisher = WebMD |title = Vetiver |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425125340/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-695-VETIVER.aspx?activeIngredientId=695&activeIngredientName=VETIVER&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Ramacham.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cinchona]]'' spec. | Cinchona | [[Genus]] of about 38 [[species]] of trees whose bark is a source of [[alkaloids]], including [[quinine]]. Its use as a [[febrifuge]] was first popularized in the 17th century by [[Peru]]vian [[Jesuits]].<ref>{{cite book | url=http://www.henriettesherbal.com/eclectic/usdisp/cinchona.html |editor1=Joseph P. Remington |editor2=Horatio C. Wood | year=1918 | title=The Dispensatory of the United States of America | chapter=Cinchona }}</ref> | [[File:Cinchona.pubescens01.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Citrus × aurantium]]'' | [[Bitter orange]] | Used in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] and by indigenous peoples of the [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]] for [[nausea]], [[indigestion]] and [[constipation]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/bitterorange/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Bitter orange |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405064628/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/bitterorange |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Bitter orange - Citrus aurantium 06.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Citrus limon]]'' | [[Lemon]] | Along with other [[citrus]]es, it has a long history of use in [[traditional Chinese medicine|Chinese]] and [[Ayurveda|Indian traditional medicine]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Citrus: the genus citrus | chapter=Citrus species and their essential oils in traditional medicine |editor1=Giovanni Dugo |editor2=Angelo Di Giacomo |author1=Antonio Imbesi |author2=Anna de Pascuale | year=2002 | publisher=CRC Press | pages=577ff. | isbn=0-415-28491-0 }}</ref> In contemporary use, honey and lemon is common for treating coughs and sore throat. | [[File:P1030323.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Citrus trifoliata]]'' | [[Trifoliate orange]], bitter orange | Fruits of ''Citrus trifoliata'' are widely used in Oriental medicine as a treatment for allergic inflammation.<ref>{{citation |pmid=17662711 |author1=Zhou H.Y. |author2=Shin E.M. |author3=Guo L.Y. |author4=Zou L.B. |author5=Xu G.H. |author6=Lee S.-H. |author7=Ze K.R. |author8=Kim E.-K. |author9=Kang S.S. |author10=Kim Y.S. |title=Anti-inflammatory activity of 21(alpha, beta)-methylmelianodiols, novel compounds from ''Poncirus trifoliata'' Rafinesque. |journal=European Journal of Pharmacology |volume=572 |issue=2–3 |pages=239–248 |year=2007 |doi=10.1016/j.ejphar.2007.07.005}}</ref> | [[File:20151019Citrus trifoliata5.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cissampelos pareira]]'' | Velvetleaf | Used for a wide variety of conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-267-ABUTA.aspx?activeIngredientId=267&activeIngredientName=ABUTA&source=3 |publisher = WebMD |title = Abuta |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150318055757/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-267-ABUTA.aspx?activeIngredientId=267&activeIngredientName=ABUTA&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-03-18 |df = }}</ref> | [[File: Diploclisia glaucescens Wynaad.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cnicus benedictus]]'' | [[Blessed thistle]] | Used during the [[Middle Ages]] to treat [[bubonic plague]]. In modern times, [[herbal tea]]s made from blessed thistle are used for [[loss of appetite]], [[indigestion]] and other purposes.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/94.html |publisher = [[National Institute of Health]] [[MedlinePlus]] |title = Blessed thistle |accessdate = 2011-10-03 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111002142318/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/94.html |archivedate = 2011-10-02 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Cnicus_benedictus_flor.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Crataegus monogyna]]'' and ''[[Crataegus laevigata]]'' | [[Crataegus|Hawthorn]] | Fruit has been used for centuries for [[heart disease]]. Other uses include digestive and kidney related problems.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/hawthorn/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Hawthorn |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405071426/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/hawthorn |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Crataegus, various species, fruit.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Curcuma longa]]'' | [[Turmeric]] | Spice that lends its distinctive yellow color to Indian curries, has long been used in [[Ayurveda|Ayurvedic]] and [[traditional Chinese medicine]] to aid digestion and liver function, relieve arthritis pain, and regulate menstruation.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/turmeric/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Turmeric |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150318220329/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/turmeric/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-18 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Native_Turmeric_Cooktown.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Cypripedium parviflorum]]'' | Yellow lady's slipper | The ''Cypripedium'' species have been used in native remedies for dermatitis, tooth aches, anxiety, headaches, as an antispasmodic, stimulant and sedative. However, the preferred species for use are ''Cyp. parviflorum'' and ''Cyp.acaule'', used as topical applications or tea.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lady's Slipper: Information on Uses, Doses, and Side Effects|url=http://www.healthline.com/natstandardcontent/ladys-slipper|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420030844/http://www.healthline.com/natstandardcontent/ladys-slipper|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 April 2009|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Cichoke|first=Anthony J|title=Secrets of Native American herbal remedies: a comprehensive guide to the Native American tradition of using herbs and the mind/body/spirit connection for improving health and well-being (|year=2001|publisher=Penguin Publisher|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WQuy8Qgib9AC&pg=PT57&lpg=PT57&dq=Native+lady+slipper+remedies&source=bl&ots=520nxBl6Xo&sig=jFpuQX-0IINrPbaSYg0orW3QpIY&hl=en&ei=I9jLTYmQMMPVgQeX6fmEBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=cypripedium&f=false}}</ref> | [[File:Cypripedium parviflorum Orchi 016.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== D ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Digitalis lanata]]'' | [[Digitalis]] or foxglove | It came into use in treating [[cardiac disease]] in late 18th century England in spite of its high toxicity.{{ref|1|a}} Its use has been almost entirely replaced by the pharmaceutical derivative [[Digoxin]], which has a shorter half-life in the body, and whose toxicity is therefore more easily managed.<ref> {{cite web |author = Arthur C. Gibson |title = The Lifesaving Foxglove |url = http://www.botgard.ucla.edu/html/botanytextbooks/economicbotany/Digitalis/index.html |work = [http://www.botgard.ucla.edu/html/botanytextbooks/economicbotany/index.html Economic Botany Manual] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111214070015/http://botgard.ucla.edu/html/botanytextbooks/economicbotany/Digitalis/index.html |archivedate = 2011-12-14 |df = }}</ref> Digoxin is used as an [[antiarrhythmic agent]] and [[inotrope]].<ref> {{cite journal |title=ABC of atrial fibrillation: drugs for atrial fibrillation |author=Lip GYH, Watson RDS, Singh SP |journal=British Medical Journal |year=1995 |volume=311 |pages=1631–1634 |pmid=8555811 |issue=7020 |pmc=2551512 |doi=10.1136/bmj.311.7020.1631 |last2=Watson |last3=Singh }}</ref> | [[File:Digitalis_lanata_Orchi_406.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== E ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Echinacea purpurea]]'' | [[Purple coneflower]] | This plant and other species of ''[[Echinacea]]'' have been used for at least 400 years by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s to treat [[infection]]s and wounds, and as a general "cure-all" ([[panacea]]). It is currently used for symptoms associated with [[common cold|cold]] and [[influenza|flu]]<ref> {{cite journal |author=Roxas M, Jurenka J |title=Colds and influenza: a review of diagnosis and conventional, botanical, and nutritional considerations |journal=Alternative Medicine Review |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=25–48 |year=2007 |pmid=17397266 |doi= |last2=Jurenka }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm |title = Echinacea |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150705013542/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-07-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Echinacea purpurea 003.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Equisetum arvense]]'' | [[Horsetail]] | Dates back to [[Ancient Rome|ancient Roman]] and [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] medicine, when it was used to stop [[bleeding]], heal [[ulcer]]s and wounds, and treat [[tuberculosis]] and [[kidney disease|kidney problems]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.truestarhealth.com/Notes/2112000.html |work = Encyclopedia of Health |title = Horsetail |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130208205554/http://www.truestarhealth.com/Notes/2112000.html |archivedate = 2013-02-08 |df = }}{{unreliable source?|date=October 2011}}{{marketing material|date=October 2011}}</ref> | [[File:Equisetum arvense foliage.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Eriodictyon crassifolium]]'' | Yerba Santa | Used by the [[Chumash people]] to keep airways open for proper breathing.<ref>{{cite journal | author=James D. Adams Jr, Cecilia Garcia | title=Palliative Care Among Chumash People | journal=ECAM | volume=3 | issue=2 | pages=143–147 | year=2005 | doi=10.1093/ecam/neh090 | pmid=15937554 | last2=Garcia | pmc=1142202 }}</ref> | [[File:Eriodictyoncrassifolium1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Eschscholzia californica]]'' | Californian poppy | Used as an [[Medicinal herb|herbal]] remedy: an [[Aqueous solution|aqueous]] [[extract]] of the plant has [[sedative]] and [[anxiolytic]] actions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rolland |first1=A. |last2=Fleurentin |first2=J. |last3=Lanhers |first3=M.C. |last4=Younos |first4=C. |last5=Misslin |first5=R. |last6=Mortier |first6=F. |last7=Mortier |first7=J.M.|title=Behavioural Effects of the American Traditional Plant Eschscholzia Californica: Sedative and Anxiolytic Properties|journal=Planta Medica|volume=57|issue=3|pages=212–216|date=June 1991 |doi=10.1055/s-2006-960076 |pmid=1680240}}</ref> | [[File:LeamingtonSpa Platform2 Eschscholzia3.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Eucalyptus globulus]]'' | [[Eucalyptus]] | Leaves were widely used in traditional medicine as a [[febrifuge]].<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.puritan.com/vf/healthnotes/hn77/hn77_english/Herb/Eucalyptus.htm |publisher = Health Notes |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |title = Eucalyptus |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090403204445/http://www.puritan.com/vf/healthnotes/HN77/HN77_english/Herb/Eucalyptus.htm |archivedate = 2009-04-03 |df = }}</ref> Eucalyptus oil is commonly used in [[over-the-counter]] cough and cold medications, as well as for an [[analgesic]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ansci.cornell.edu/plants/medicinal/eucalyp.html |title = Eucalyptus spp. |work = Medicinal Plants for Livestock |publisher = [[Cornell University]] Department of Animal Science |accessdate = 2011-10-17 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110927115534/http://www.ansci.cornell.edu/plants/medicinal/eucalyp.html |archivedate = 2011-09-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Eucalyptus globulus (15345095225).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Euonymus atropurpureus]]'' | Wahoo | Plant is a purgative and might affect the heart.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-349-WAHOO.aspx?activeIngredientId=349&activeIngredientName=WAHOO&source=3 |title = Wahoo |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425113500/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-349-WAHOO.aspx?activeIngredientId=349&activeIngredientName=WAHOO&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Euphorbia hirta]]'' | [[Asthma-plant]] | Used traditionally in Asia to treat bronchitic asthma and laryngeal spasm.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[Plants for a Future]] |url = http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Euphorbia+hirta |title = Euphorbia hirta |accessdate = 2011-10-17 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235112/http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Euphorbia+hirta |archivedate = 2016-03-03 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Encyclopedia Of Herbs & Herbalism | author=Malcolm Stuart | isbn=0-517-35326-1 | publisher=Crescent | year=1987 }}</ref> It is used in the [[Philippines]] for [[dengue fever]].<ref>{{cite news | title=DoH sees hope in 'tawa-tawa' as dengue cure | publisher=[[Manila Bulletin]] | date=August 26, 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref> | [[File:Euphorbia hirta 2782.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Euterpe oleracea]]'' | [[Açai]] | Although açai berries are a longstanding food source for indigenous people of the [[Amazon basin|Amazon]], there is no evidence that they have historically served a medicinal, as opposed to [[nutrition]]al role. In spite of their recent popularity in the United States as a [[dietary supplement]], there is currently no evidence for their effectiveness for any health-related purpose.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/acai/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Açai |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405124024/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/acai |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | |}
== F ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Ferula assa-foetida]]'' | [[Asafoetida]] | Might be useful for [[Irritable bowel syndrome|IBS]], high [[cholesterol]], and breathing problems.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[WebMD]] |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-248-ASAFOETIDA.aspx?activeIngredientId=248&activeIngredientName=ASAFOETIDA&source=3 |title = Asafoetida |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150318040653/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-248-ASAFOETIDA.aspx?activeIngredientId=248&activeIngredientName=ASAFOETIDA&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-03-18 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Frangula alnus]]'' | Alder buckthorn | Bark (and to a lesser extent the fruit) has been used as a [[laxative]], due to its 3 – 7% [[Natural anthraquinone|anthraquinone]] content. Bark for medicinal use is dried and stored for a year before use, as fresh bark is violently purgative; even dried bark can be dangerous if taken in excess.<ref>Rushforth, K. (1999). ''Trees of Britain and Europe''. Collins {{ISBN|0-00-220013-9}}.</ref> | [[File:Frangula-alnus-fruits.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Fumaria officinalis]]'' | Fumitory | Traditionally thought to be good for the eyes and to remove skin [[Acne vulgaris|blemishes]]. In modern times herbalists use it to treat [[skin disease]]s and [[conjunctivitis]], as well as to cleanse the [[kidney]]s. However, Howard (1987) warns that fumitory is [[poison]]ous and should only be used under the direction of a medical herbalist.<ref>Howard, Michael. ''Traditional Folk Remedies'' (century, 1987). pp 142-3.</ref> | [[File:FUMARIA OFFICINALIS - AGUDA - IB-074 (Fumària).JPG|200x200px]]
|}
== G ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Galanthus]]'' | [[Snowdrop]] | It contains an active substance called [[galantamine]], which is an [[acetylcholinesterase inhibitor]]. Galantamine (or galanthamine) can be helpful in the treatment of [[Alzheimer's disease]], though it is not a cure.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Loy|first=C|last2=Schneider|date=25 Jan 2006|title=Galantamine for Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment.|pmid=16437436|journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev|volume=|page=CD001747|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001747.pub3|issue=1}}</ref> | [[File:The Washbrook Lane Snowdrops.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Geranium robertianum]]'' | Robert geranium | In traditional [[herbalism]], it was used as a remedy for toothache and nosebleeds<ref>{{citation|last=Foster|first=Steven|title=Desk Reference To Nature's Medicine|year=2006|publisher=National Geographic Society|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-7922-3666-1|pages=210–11}}</ref> and as a [[vulnerary]] (used for or useful in healing wounds).<ref name=Milliken>{{citation|last1=Milliken|first1=W.|last2=Bridgewater|first2=S.|year=2004|title=Flora Celtica|location=Edinburgh, U.K.|publisher=Birlinn Ltd.|isbn=1841583030|page=221}}</ref> | [[File:Geranium Robertianum - Detail - Blossom.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Ginkgo biloba]]'' | [[Ginkgo]] | The leaf extract has been used to treat [[asthma]], [[bronchitis]], [[Fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[Alzheimer's]] and [[tinnitus]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/ginkgo/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Ginkgo |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150329002308/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/ginkgo/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-29 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Ginkgo biloba 010.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Glechoma hederacea]]'' | Ground-ivy | It has been used as a "lung herb".<ref>[https://archive.is/20120722184543/http://www.courant.com/hc-healthhomehealing.artjun12,0,6251385.story A Healing Heritage], June 12, 2007, Joanna Poncavage, The Morning Call (Allentown, Pa.)</ref> Other traditional uses include as an expectorant, astringent, and to treat [[bronchitis]].<ref name="barnes">Joanne Barnes, Linda A. Anderson, J. David Phillipson, ''Herbal Medicines'', 2nd ed., Pharmaceutical Press, London, 2002.</ref> The [[essential oil]] of the plant has been used for centuries as a general [[Pharmaceutical drug#For nutrition|tonic]] for [[common cold|cold]]s and [[cough]]s, and to relieve [[Nasal congestion|congestion]] of the [[mucous membrane]]s. | [[File:20150412Glechoma hederacea1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Glycyrrhiza glabra]]'' | [[Licorice root]] | It has a long history of medicinal usage in Eastern and Western medicine. Uses include [[stomach ulcer]]s, [[bronchitis]], and [[sore throat]], as well as [[infection]]s caused by [[virus]]es, such as [[hepatitis]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/licoriceroot/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Licorice root |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150322111212/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/licoriceroot |archivedate = 2015-03-22 |df = }}</ref> | |}
== H ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Hamamelis virginiana]]'' | Common witch-hazel | It produces a specific kind of tannins called ''[[hamamelitannin]]s''. One of those substances displays a specific cytotoxic activity against [[colon cancer]] cells.<ref>Hamamelitannin from Witch Hazel (Hamamelis virginiana) Displays Specific Cytotoxic Activity against Colon Cancer Cells. Susana Sánchez-Tena, María L. Fernández-Cachón, Anna Carreras, M. Luisa Mateos-Martín, Noelia Costoya, Mary P. Moyer, María J. Nuñez, Josep L. Torres and Marta Cascante, J. Nat. Prod., Publication Date (Web): January 4, 2012, {{doi|10.1021/np200426k}}</ref>
| [[File:Witch Hazel.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Hippophae rhamnoides]]'' | [[Sea buckthorn]] | The leaves are used as herbal medicine to alleviate cough and fever, pain, and general gastrointestinal disorders as well as to cure dermatologic disorders. Similarly, the fruit juice and oils can be used in the treatment of liver disease, gastrointestinal disorders, chronic wounds or other dermatological disorders.<ref name="Guliyev 2004">{{cite journal|last1=Guliyev|first1=Vahid Bilaloglu|last2=Mustafa|first2=Gul|last3=Yildirim|first3=Ali|title=Hippophae rhamnoides L.: chromatographic methods to determine chemical composition, use in traditional medicine and pharmacological effects|journal=ournal of Chromatography B|date=2004|volume=812|pages=291–307|doi=10.1016/j.jchromb.2004.08.047}}</ref> | [[File:Common sea-buckthorn - Sanddorn (9049824936).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Hoodia gordonii]]'' | [[Hoodia]] | The plant is traditionally used by [[Kalahari]] [[San people|San]] (Bushmen) to reduce [[hunger]] and [[thirst]]. It is currently marketed as an [[appetite suppressant]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/hoodia/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Hoodia |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405071510/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/hoodia |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Hydrastis canadensis]]'' | [[Goldenseal]] | It was used traditionally by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s to treat [[skin disease]]s, ulcers, and [[gonorrhea]]. More recently, the herb has been used to treat the [[respiratory tract infection|respiratory tract]] and a number of other [[infection|infections.]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/goldenseal/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Goldenseal |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150325172201/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/goldenseal |archivedate = 2015-03-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Hydrastis.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Hypericum perforatum]]'' | [[St. John's wort]] | Widely used within herbalism for depression. Evaluated for use as an [[antidepressant]], but with ambiguous results.<ref> {{cite journal |pages=152–6 |doi=10.1001/archinte.160.2.152 |title=St John's Wort for Depression: A Systematic Review |year=2000 |last1=Gaster |first1=B. |journal=Archives of Internal Medicine |volume=160 |issue=2 |pmid=10647752 |last2=Holroyd |first2=J}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |pages=1807–14 |doi=10.1001/jama.287.14.1807 |title=Effect of Hypericum perforatum (St John's Wort) in Major Depressive Disorder: A Randomized Controlled Trial |year=2002 |last1=Hypericum Depression Trial Study Group |journal=JAMA |volume=287 |issue=14 |pmid=11939866}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/stjohnswort/ataglance.htm |title = St. John's wort |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150206050029/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/stjohnswort/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-02-06 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Saint John's wort flowers.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== I ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Ilex paraguariensis]]'' | Yerba mate | It has been claimed to have various effects on human health and these effects have been attributed to the high quantity of [[polyphenol]]s found in mate tea.<ref name=Gambero2015>{{cite journal|vauthors=Gambero A, Ribeiro ML |title=The positive effects of yerba maté (Ilex paraguariensis) in obesity|journal=Nutrients|volume=7|issue=2|pages=730–50|date=January 2015| pmid= 25621503| pmc= 4344557| doi= 10.3390/nu7020730}}</ref> Mate contains compounds that act as an appetite suppressant,<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Wichtl |editor-first=Max |title=Herbal Drugs and Phytopharmaceuticals |year=2004 |publisher=Medpharm |isbn=0849319617}}</ref> increases mental energy and focus,<ref name="Arch Latinoam Nutr">{{cite journal |last1=Sanz |first1=Tenorio |last2=Isasa |first2=Torija |year= 1991 |title=Mineral elements in mate herb (Ilex paraguariensis St. H.) |journal=Arch Latinoam Nutr |volume=41 |issue=3 |pages= 441–454 |publisher=Arch Latinoam Nutr|pmid=1824521 }}</ref> and improves mood.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Klein |first1=Siegrid |last2= Rister |first2=Robert| title= The Complete German Commission E Monographs: Therapeutic Guide to Herbal Medicines|year=1998 |publisher=The American Botanical Council |isbn=096555550X}}</ref> Yerba mate also contains elements such as [[potassium]], [[magnesium]], and [[manganese]].<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Eunice |last1=Valduga |first2=Renato João Sossela |last2=de Freitas |first3=Carlos B. |last3=Reissmann |first4=Tomoe |last4=Nakashima |year=1997 |title=Caracterização química da folha de ''Ilex paraguariensis'' St. Hil. (erva-mate) e de outras espécies utilizadas na adulteração do mate |url=http://ojs.c3sl.ufpr.br/ojs-2.2.4/index.php/alimentos/article/viewArticle/14033 |language=Portuguese |journal=Boletim do Centro de Pesquisa de Processamento de Alimentos |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=25–36 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826122045/http://ojs.c3sl.ufpr.br/ojs-2.2.4/index.php/alimentos/article/viewArticle/14033 |archivedate=2014-08-26 |df= }}</ref> | [[File:Ilexparaguariensis.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Illicium verum]]'' | [[Star anise]] | It is the major source of the chemical compound [[shikimic acid]], a primary precursor in the pharmaceutical synthesis of anti-[[influenza]] drug [[oseltamivir]] (Tamiflu).<ref name=Wang>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = G. W. | last2 = Hu | first2 = W. T. | last3 = Huang | first3 = B. K. | last4 = Qin | first4 = L. P. | title = ''Illicium verum'': A review on its botany, traditional use, chemistry and pharmacology | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2011.04.051 | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 136 | issue = 1 | pages = 10–20 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21549817| pmc = }}</ref> | [[File:Illicium verum in HDR.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Inula helenium]]'' | [[Elecampane]] | It is used in [[herbal medicine]] as an [[expectorant]] and for [[Water retention (medicine)|water retention]].<ref>{{Cite book | author = Bartram, T. | date = 1998 | title = Bartram’s Encyclopedia of Herbal Medicine | location = London | publisher = Robinson Publishing Ltd | isbn = 978-1854875860}}</ref> | [[File:Composite1.JPG|200x200px]]
|}

{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Jasminum officinale]]'' | Jasmine | It is used in [[dermatology]] as either an [[antiseptic]] or [[anti-inflammatory|anti-inflammatory agent]].<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book |author=Rapini, Ronald P. |author2=Bolognia, Jean L. |author3=Jorizzo, Joseph L. |title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set |publisher=Mosby |location=St. Louis |year=2007 |pages=2049 |isbn=1-4160-2999-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> | [[File:Jasminum officinale Enfoque 2010-7-11 TorrelaMata.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== K ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Knautia arvensis]]'' | Field scabious | The whole plant is astringent and mildly diuretic. An infusion is used internally as a blood purifier and externally for treating cuts, burns and bruises.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalmedicinalherbs.net/herbs/k/knautia-arvensis=field-scabious.php|title=Naturalmedicinalherbs website|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107091245/http://www.naturalmedicinalherbs.net/herbs/k/knautia-arvensis=field-scabious.php|archivedate=2016-11-07|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Knautia arvensis20110703 116.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== L ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Larrea tridentata]]'' | [[Chaparral]] | The leaves and twigs are used by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s to make a [[herbal tea]] used for a variety of conditions, including [[arthritis]], [[cancer]] and a number of others. Subsequent studies have been extremely variable, at best. Chaparral has also been shown to have high liver toxicity, and has led to [[kidney failure]], and is not recommended for any use by the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) or [[American Cancer Society]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Alternative Medicine: The Christian Handbook |author1=Dónal O'Mathúna |author2=Walt Larimore | publisher=Zondervan | year=2001 | isbn=0-310-23584-7 | page=318 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cancer.org/Treatment/TreatmentsandSideEffects/ComplementaryandAlternativeMedicine/HerbsVitaminsandMinerals/chaparral |title = Chaparral |work = Herbs, Vitamins, and Minerals |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111002165416/http://www.cancer.org/Treatment/TreatmentsandSideEffects/ComplementaryandAlternativeMedicine/HerbsVitaminsandMinerals/chaparral |archivedate = 2011-10-02 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Larrea tridentata Furnace Creek.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Laurus nobilis]]'' | Bay laurel | [[Aqueous solution|Aqueous]] [[extract]]s of bay laurel can be used as [[astringent]]s and even as a reasonable salve for open wounds.<ref name=Nayak>Nayak, ''et al''. (2006).</ref> In [[massage therapy]], the essential oil of bay laurel is reputed to alleviate arthritis and rheumatism, while in [[aromatherapy]] it is used to treat earaches and high blood pressure.<ref name=AllNat>{{cite web |url=http://www.allnatural.net/herbpages/bay-laurel.shtml |title=Bay Laurel: Laurus nobilis |author=Encyclopedia of Herbs |publisher=AllNatural.net |accessdate=2010-12-31 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101119205731/http://allnatural.net/herbpages/bay-laurel.shtml| archivedate= 19 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> | [[File:Gardenology-IMG 4930 hunt10mar.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Lavandula angustifolia]]'' | [[Lavender]] | It was traditionally used as an antiseptic and for [[mental health]] purposes. It was also used in [[ancient Egypt]] in [[mummy|mummifying]] bodies. There is little scientific evidence that lavender is effective for most mental health uses.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/lavender/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Lavender |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150118174411/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/lavender/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-01-18 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Lavande off FR 2012.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Henna|Lawsonia inermis]]'' | [[Henna]] | The plants exhibits potential antibacterial activity. The alcoholic extract of the root has antibacterial activity due to the presence of flavonoid and alkaloids. Henna is also thought to show anti-inflammatory, antipyretic, and analgesic effects in experimental animals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alia|first=BH|author2=AK, Bashir|author3=MOM, Tanira|title=Anti-Inflammatory, Antipyretic, and Analgesic Effects of Lawsonia inermis L. (Henna) in Rats|journal=International Journal of Experimental and Clinical Pharmacology|volume=51|issue=6|url=http://www.karger.com/Article/Abstract/139347|accessdate=11 April 2014|doi=10.1159/000139347|pages=356–363|year=1995|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413125300/http://www.karger.com/Article/Abstract/139347|archivedate=13 April 2014|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Lawsonia inermis (Mehndi) in Hyderabad, AP W IMG 0524.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Leucojum aestivum]]'' | Summer snowflake | It is known to contain Galantamine (Nivalin, Razadyne, Razadyne ER, Reminyl, Lycoremine in pharmaceutical format). It is used for the treatment of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease and various other memory impairments, in particular those of vascular origin. | [[File:Leucojum aestivum 2010.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Linum usitatissimum]]'' | [[Flaxseed]] | The plant is most commonly used as a [[laxative]]. [[Flaxseed oil]] is used for different conditions, including [[arthritis]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/flaxseed/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Flaxseed |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150326090842/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/flaxseed/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-26 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Lin (Everest) Cl J Weber04 (23715892009).jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== M ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Magnolia officinalis]]'' | Magnolia-bark | The bark contains [[magnolol]] and [[honokiol]], two polyphenolic compounds. Preclinical studies have evaluated their various potential applications including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antitumor, and antimicrobial properties.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Honokiol and magnolol as multifunctional antioxidative molecules for dermatologic disorders.|date = Sep 16, 2010|journal = Molecules |doi = 10.3390/molecules15096452|pmid = 20877235 |volume=15 |pages=6452–65 |author=Shen JL, Man KM, Huang PH, Chen WC, Chen DC, Cheng YW, Liu PL, Chou MC, Chen YH}}</ref> | [[File:Magnolia au Jardin Jungle Karlostachys.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Malva sylvestris]]'' | Mallow | The seeds are used internally in a [[decoction]] or herbal tea<ref>{{cite book|title=International Medical and Surgical Survey: Obstetrics and pediatrics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4W43AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA143|accessdate=11 December 2013|year=1921|publisher=American Institute of Medicine|page=143}}</ref> as a [[demulcent]] and [[diuretic]], and the leaves made into [[poultice]]s as an [[emollient]] for external applications. | [[File:Malva sylvestris 1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Matricaria recutita]]'' and ''[[Anthemis nobilis]]'' | [[Chamomile]] | It has been used over thousands of years for a variety of conditions, including sleeplessness, anxiety, and gastrointestinal conditions such as [[upset stomach]], gas, and [[diarrhea]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/chamomile/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Chamomile |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150329022843/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/chamomile/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-29 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:MATRICARIA RECUTITA - TORÀ - IB-418 (Camamilla).JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Medicago sativa]]'' | [[Alfalfa]] | The leaves are used to lower [[cholesterol]], as well as forum [[kidney disease|kidney]] and [[urinary tract]] ailments, although there is insufficient scientific evidence for its efficacy.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/19.html |publisher = [[National Institute of Health]] [[MedlinePlus]] |title = Alfalfa |accessdate = 2011-09-29 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111002142117/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/19.html |archivedate = 2011-10-02 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Melaleuca alternifolia]]'' | [[Tea tree oil]] | It has been used medicinally for centuries by Australian aboriginal people. Modern usage is primarily as an [[antibacterial]] or [[Antifungal medication|antifungal]] agent.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/tea/treeoil.htm |title = Tea tree oil |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150324031853/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/tea/treeoil.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-24 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Melaleuca_alternifolia_(Maria_Serena).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Melissa officinalis]]'' | [[Lemon balm]] | It is used as a sleep aid and digestive aid.<ref>{{cite web|title=Monograph: Lemon Balm|url=http://webprod.hc-sc.gc.ca/nhpid-bdipsn/monoReq.do?id=125|publisher=Health Canada|accessdate=8 October 2016|date=17 March 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330022950/http://webprod.hc-sc.gc.ca/nhpid-bdipsn/monoReq.do?id=125|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Melissa officinalis J2.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Mentha x piperita]]'' | [[Peppermint]] | Its oil, from a cross between [[water mint]] and [[spearmint]], has a history of medicinal use for a variety of conditions, including [[nausea]], [[indigestion]], and symptoms of the [[common cold]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/peppermintoil/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Peppermint Oil |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405072941/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/peppermintoil |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Mentha-piperita.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Mitragyna speciosa]]'' | [[Kratom]] | Kratom is known to prevent or delay withdrawal symptoms in an opioid-dependent individual, and it is often used to mitigate cravings thereafter. It can also be used for other medicinal purposes. Kratom has been traditionally used in regions such as Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Herbal|url=http://www.jual-hajarjahanamcair.com|website=Herbal|accessdate=9 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704163248/http://www.jual-hajarjahanamcair.com/|archivedate=4 July 2016|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Mitragyna_speciosa111.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Momordica charantia]]'' | [[Bitter melon]] | The plant is used as an agent to reduce the blood glucose level.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Baldwa VS, Bhandari CM, Pangaria A, Goyal RK |title=Clinical trial in patients with diabetes mellitus of an insulin-like compound obtained from plant source |journal=Upsala Journal of Medical Sciences |volume=82 |pages=39–41 |year=1977 |doi=10.3109/03009737709179057 |pmid=20078273 |issue=1|last2=Bhandari |last3=Pangaria |last4=Goyal }}</ref> | [[File:012 bitter melon.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Morinda citrifolia]]'' | [[Noni]] | It has a history of use as for joint pain and [[skin disease|skin conditions]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/noni/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Noni |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405072806/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/noni |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:P Morc D5915.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Moringa oleifera]]'' | Drumstick tree | It is used for food and traditional medicine. It is undergoing preliminary research to investigate potential properties of its nutrients and phytochemicals | [[File:DrumstickFlower.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== N ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Nasturtium officinale]]'' | [[Watercress]] | It may be diuretic and antibacterial.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-346-WATERCRESS.aspx?activeIngredientId=346&activeIngredientName=WATERCRESS&source=3 |title = Watercress |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425092419/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-346-WATERCRESS.aspx?activeIngredientId=346&activeIngredientName=WATERCRESS&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Flowers of Watercress (Nasturtium officinale).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Nelumbo nucifera]]'' | [[Lotus (genus)|Lotus]] | Sacred lotus has been the subject of a number of in-vitro and animal studies, exploring its pharmacologic effects, including antioxidant, hepatoprotective, immunomodulatory, anti-infective, hyperlipidemic, and psychopharmacologic activity<ref>{{cite web |title = Sacred Lotus |publisher = Drugs.com |url = https://www.drugs.com/npp/sacred-lotus.html |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170718063014/https://www.drugs.com/npp/sacred-lotus.html |archivedate = 2017-07-18 |df = }}</ref> although clinical trials are lacking. | [[File:Nelumbo nucifera1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Nigella sativa]]'' | Nigella, black-caraway, black-cumin, and ''kalonji'' | It has efficacy as a [[therapy]], mainly using the [[seed oil]] extract, [[volatile oil]], and isolated constituent [[thymoquinone]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ali BH, Blunden G |title=Pharmacological and toxicological properties of Nigella sativa |journal=Phytother Res |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=299–305 |year=2003 |pmid=12722128 |doi=10.1002/ptr.1309 }}</ref> One meta-analysis of clinical trials concluded that ''N. sativa'' has a short-term benefit on lowering [[systolic blood pressure|systolic]] and [[diastolic blood pressure]].<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Sahebkar A, Soranna D, Liu X, et al. |title=A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials investigating the effects of supplementation with Nigella sativa (black seed) on blood pressure |journal=J Hypertens |volume=34 |issue=11 |pages=2127–35 |year=2016 |pmid=27512971 |doi=10.1097/HJH.0000000000001049 }}</ref> | [[File:Nigella sativa.jpg|200x200px]] |}
== O ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Ocimum tenuiflorum]]'' | [[Tulsi]] or Holy Basil | It is used for a variety of purposes in medicine tulasi is taken in many forms: as herbal tea, dried powder, fresh leaf or mixed with ghee. Essential oil extracted from Karpoora tulasi is mostly used for medicinal purposes and in herbal cosmetics.<ref>{{cite book|last=NIIR Board, National Institute of Industrial Research (India)|title=Compendium of Medicinal Plants|publisher=National Institute of Industrial Research|series=2004|isbn=978-81-86623-80-0|page=320|year=2004}}</ref> | [[File:Ocimum_tenuiflorum2.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Oenothera]]'' | [[Evening primrose]] | Its [[evening primrose oil|oil]] has been used since the 1930s for [[eczema]], and more recently as an [[anti-inflammatory]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/eveningprimrose/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Evening primrose oil |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150323213829/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/eveningprimrose |archivedate = 2015-03-23 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Origanum vulgare]]'' | [[Oregano]] | Used as an abortifacient in folk medicine in some parts of Bolivia and other northwestern South American countries, though no evidence of efficacy exists in Western medicine. Hippocrates used oregano as an antiseptic, as well as a cure for stomach and respiratory ailments. A Cretan oregano (''O. dictamnus'') is still used today in Greece as a palliative for sore throat. Evidence of efficacy in this matter is lacking. | [[File:Origanum-vulgare.JPG|200x200px]]
|}
== P ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Panax]]'' spec. | [[Ginseng]] | Used medicinally, in particular in Asia, for over 2,000 years, and is widely used in modern society.<ref>{{cite book | title=Alternative Medicine: The Christian Handbook |author1=Dónal O'Mathúna |author2=Walt Larimore | publisher=Zondervan | year=2001 | isbn=0-310-23584-7 | pages=371–372 }}</ref> | [[File:Ginsengpflanze.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Papaver somniferum]]'' | [[Opium poppy]] | The plant is the plant source of [[morphine]], used for [[pain]] relief. Morphine made from the refined and modified sap is used for pain control in terminally ill patients. Dried sap was used as a traditional medicine until the 19th century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} | [[File:Opium_poppy.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Passiflora]]'' | [[Passion flower]] | Thought to have anti-depressant properties. Unknown MOA. Used in traditional medicine to aid with sleep or depression. {{anchor|Q}} | [[File:Passiflora Krishnakamal Karnataka India.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Peganum harmala]]'' | [[Syrian Rue]] (aka [[Harmal]]) | Can be used as an antidepressant, but carries significant risk. Used in traditional shamanistic rites in the amazon, and is a component of Ayahuasca, Caapi or Yajé (which is actually usually ''[[Banisteriopsis caapi]]'' but has the same active alkaloids). | [[File:Peganum harmala 20140604.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Pelargonium sidoides]]'' | [[Umckaloabo]], or [[South African Geranium]] | It is used in treating acute [[bronchitis]]<ref>{{cite journal | title=Efficacy and tolerability of EPs 7630 in children and adolescents with acute bronchitis: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled multicenter trial with a herbal drug preparation from Pelargonium sidoides roots | author=Kamin W., Maydannik V., Malek F.A., Kieser M. | journal=International Journal of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics | year=2010 | volume=48 | issue=3 | pages=184–191 | pmid=20197012 | doi=10.5414/cpp48184 | last2=Maydannik | last3=Malek | last4=Kieser }}</ref> | [[File:Pelargonium_sidoides_Leaves_3264px.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Piper methysticum]]'' | [[Kava]] | The plant has been used for centuries in the [[Oceania|South Pacific]] to make a ceremonial drink with [[sedative]] and [[anesthetic]] properties. It is used as a [[soporific]], as well as for [[asthma]] and urinary tract infection<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/kava/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Kava |accessdate = 20- 11-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527123009/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/kava |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Starr 070515-7054 Piper methysticum.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Piscidia erythrina]]'' / ''[[Piscidia piscipula]]'' | [[Jamaica dogwood]] | The plant is used in traditional medicine for the treatment of [[insomnia]] and [[anxiety]], despite serious safety concerns.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-529-JAMAICAN%20DOGWOOD.aspx?activeIngredientId=529&activeIngredientName=JAMAICAN%20DOGWOOD |title = Jamaica dogwood |publisher = WebMD |accessdate = 2013-08-26 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150912051445/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-529-jamaican%20dogwood.aspx?activeingredientid=529&activeingredientname=jamaican%20dogwood |archivedate = 2015-09-12 |df = }}</ref> A 2006 study suggested medicinal potential.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=89–97 |doi=10.1002/jps.3030370302 |title=An investigation of Piscidia erythrina (Jamaica dogwood) |year=2006 |last1=Costello |first1=Christopher H. |last2=Butler |first2=Calvin L. |journal=Journal of the American Pharmaceutical Association |volume=37 |issue=3 |pmid=18905805}}</ref> | |- | ''[[Plantago lanceolata]] | Plantain | It is used frequently in [[herbal tea]]s and other [[Herbalism|herbal remedies]].<ref>[http://www.valplantes.ch/definition.html Val plantes herbal ice tea] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725234116/http://www.valplantes.ch/definition.html |date=2009-07-25 }}</ref> A tea from the leaves is used as a highly effective cough medicine. In the traditional Austrian medicine ''Plantago lanceolata'' leaves have been used internally (as syrup or tea) or externally (fresh leaves) for treatment of disorders of the respiratory tract, skin, insect bites, and infections.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Vogl S, Picker P, Mihaly-Bison J, etal |title=Ethnopharmacological in vitro studies on Austria's folk medicine--an unexplored lore in vitro anti-inflammatory activities of 71 Austrian traditional herbal drugs |journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology |volume=149 |issue=3 |pages=750–71 | date=October 2013 |pmid=23770053 |pmc=3791396 |doi=10.1016/j.jep.2013.06.007}}</ref> | [[File:20120610Reilinger See1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Platycodon grandiflorus]]'' | Platycodon, balloon flower | The extracts and purified platycoside compounds ([[saponins]]) from the roots may exhibit neuroprotective, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, anti-allergy, improved insulin resistance, and cholesterol-lowering properties.<ref name="ReviewArticle2014">{{cite journal | pmid = 25054103 | doi=10.3746/pnf.2014.19.2.059 | volume=19 | title=Platycosides from the Roots of Platycodon grandiflorum and Their Health Benefits | pmc=4103729 | author=Nyakudya E, Jeong JH, Lee NK, Jeong YS | journal=Prev Nutr Food Sci | pages=59–68 | year=2014}}</ref> | [[File:Platycodon grandiflorus.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Polemonium reptans]]'' | Abscess root | It is used to reduce fever, inflammation, and cough.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-266-ABSCESS+ROOT.aspx?activeIngredientId=266&activeIngredientName=ABSCESS+ROOT&source=3 |publisher = WebMD |title = Abscess Root |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150318035713/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-266-ABSCESS+ROOT.aspx?activeIngredientId=266&activeIngredientName=ABSCESS+ROOT&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-03-18 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Jacob's Ladder Polemonium reptens Flower Buds 2628px.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Psidium guajava]]'' | [[Guava]] | It has a rich history of use in traditional medicine. It is traditionally used to treat diarrhea; however, evidence of its effectiveness is very limited.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = Drugs.com |url = https://www.drugs.com/npp/guava.html |title = Guava |accessdate = 2011-10-17 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110812094858/http://www.drugs.com/npp/guava.html |archivedate = 2011-08-12 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=J. Hawrelak | title=Medicinal herb monograph: Guava | journal=J Aust Tradit-Med Soc | year=2003 | issue=9 | pages=25–29 }}</ref> | [[File:Psidium guajava at Kadavoor.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Ptelea trifoliata]]'' | Wafer Ash | The root bark is used for the digestive system.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-207-WAFER+ASH.aspx?activeIngredientId=207&activeIngredientName=WAFER+ASH&source=3 |title = Wafer Ash |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425175043/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-207-WAFER+ASH.aspx?activeIngredientId=207&activeIngredientName=WAFER+ASH&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> Also known as hoptree. | [[File:Ptelea trifoliata 20050808 006.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
