== R ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Rosa majalis]]'' | Cinnamon rose | It yields edible [[rose hip|hip fruits]] rich in [[vitamin C]], which are used in medicine<ref>{{cite web|title=Fruit teas Rose (Rosa vosagiaca, rosa majalis, rosa canina, rosa rugosa etc.)|url=http://www.gurmans.fi/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26&Itemid=21&lang=en|publisher=Gurmans|accessdate=6 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130412154043/http://www.gurmans.fi/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26&Itemid=21&lang=en|archivedate=12 April 2013|df=}}</ref> and to produce rose hip syrup. | [[File:Rosa majalis20140910 02.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Rosmarinus officinalis]]'' | [[Rosemary]] | It has been used medicinally from ancient times. | [[File:Shinasahi142211.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Ruellia tuberosa]]'' | Minnieroot, fever root, snapdragon root |In folk medicine and Ayurvedic medicine it has been used as a [[diuretic]], [[anti-diabetic]], [[antipyretic]], [[analgesic]], [[antihypertensive]], [[Peptic ulcer#Treatment|gastroprotective]], and to treat [[gonorrhea]].<ref>Lans C.A., ''Ethnomedicine as used in Trinidad and Tobago for urinary problems and diabetes mellitus;'' J. Ethnobiol. Ethnomed. 200</ref> | [[File:Ruellia tuberosa (Wayside Tuberose) in Hyderabad W IMG 9012.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Rumex crispus]]'' | Curly dock or yellow dock | In Western herbalism the root is often used for treating anemia, due to its high level of iron.<ref>Lust, John B.. The herb book. New York: B. Lust Publications, 1974.</ref> The plant will help with skin conditions if taken internally or applied externally to things like itching, scrofula, and sores. It is also used for respiratory conditions, specifically those with a tickling cough that is worse when exposed to cold air. It mentions also passing pains, excessive itching, and that it helps enlarged lymphs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abchomeopathy.com/r.php/Rumx|title=Rumex Crispus|author=|date=|website=abchomeopathy.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20140306202449/http://abchomeopathy.com/r.php/Rumx|archivedate=2014-03-06|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Polygonaceae - Rumex crispus-1 (8303634985).jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== S ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Salix alba]]'' | [[White willow]] | Plant source of [[salicylic acid]], white willow is like the chemical known as [[aspirin]], although more likely to cause [[upset stomach|stomach upset]] as a [[side effect]] than [[aspirin]] itself which can cause the lining in your stomach to be destroyed. Used from ancient times for the same uses as [[aspirin]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mahdi JG, Mahdi AJ, Mahdi AJ, Bowen ID | title=The historical analysis of aspirin discovery, its relation to the willow tree and antiproliferative and anticancer potential | journal=Cell Proliferation | year=2006 | volume=39 | issue=2 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2184.2006.00377.x | pages=147–155 | pmid=16542349 }}</ref> | [[File:Salix_alba_leaves.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Salvia officinalis]]'' | Sage | Shown to improve cognitive function in patients with mild to moderate [[Alzheimer's disease]]<ref>{{cite journal |pages=53–9 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2710.2003.00463.x |title=Salvia officinalis extract in the treatment of patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease: A double blind, randomized and placebo-controlled trial |year=2003 |last1=Akhondzadeh |first1=S. |last2=Noroozian |first2=M. |last3=Mohammadi |first3=M. |last4=Ohadinia |first4=S. |last5=Jamshidi |first5=A. H. |last6=Khani |first6=M. |journal=Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics |volume=28 |pmid=12605619 |issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/sage/ |title = Sage |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527114449/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/sage |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Salvia officinalis 001.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Sambucus nigra]]'' | [[Elderberry]] | The berries and leaves have traditionally been used to treat [[pain]], [[swelling (medical)|swelling]], [[infection]]s, [[cough]]s, and [[skin disease|skin conditions]] and, more recently, [[flu]], [[common cold]], [[fever]]s, [[constipation]], and [[sinus infection]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/euroelder/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = European Elderberry |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405061358/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/euroelder |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Sambucus-berries.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Santalum album]]'' | [[Indian sandalwood]] | Sandalwood oil has been widely used in folk medicine for treatment of [[common colds]], [[bronchitis]], [[skin disorders]], heart ailments, general weakness, [[fever]], infection of the urinary tract, inflammation of the mouth and pharynx, liver and gallbladder complaints and other maladies.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Misra | first1 = BB | last2 = Dey | first2 = S | year = 2013 | title = Biological Activities of East Indian Sandalwood Tree, Santalum album | url = | journal = PeerJ PrePrints | volume = 1 | issue = | page = e96 | doi = 10.7287/peerj.preprints.96v1 }}</ref> | [[File:Santalum album leaves and flowers 06.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Santolina chamaecyparissus]]'' | Cotton lavender | Most commonly, the flowers and leaves are made into a [[decoction]] used to expel [[intestinal parasite]]s. | [[File:Santolina chamaecyparissus flowers.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Saraca indica]]'' | [[Ashoka tree]] | The plant is used in Ayurvedic traditions to treat gynecological disorders. The bark is also used to combat oedema or swelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tamilnadu.com/herbs/ashoka.html |title=Herbs - Ashoka |publisher=Tamilnadu.com |date=25 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411231150/http://tamilnadu.com/herbs/ashoka.html |archivedate=11 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> | [[File:Gardenology.org-IMG 7344 qsbg11mar.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Satureja hortensis]]'' | [[Summer savory]] | Its extracts show antibacterial and antifungal effects on several species including some of the antibiotic resistant strains.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=3958–3965 |doi=10.1021/jf0340308 |pmid=12822930 |title=In Vitro Antibacterial, Antifungal, and Antioxidant Activities of the Essential Oil and Methanol Extracts of Herbal Parts and Callus Cultures of Satureja hortensis L |year=2003 |last1=Güllüce |first1=M. |last2=Sökmen |first2=M. |last3=Daferera |first3=D. |last4=Aǧar |first4=G. |last5=Özkan |first5=H. |last6=Kartal |first6=N. |last7=Polissiou |first7=M. |last8=Sökmen |first8=A. |last9=Şahi̇n |first9=F. |journal=J. Agric. Food Chem. |volume=51 |issue=14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pages=61–65 |doi=10.1016/S0378-8741(03)00110-7 |pmid=12787955 |title=Evaluation of antimicrobial activities of Satureja hortensis L |year=2003 |last1=Şahin |first1=F. |last2=Karaman |first2=İ. |last3=Güllüce |first3=M. |last4=Öğütçü |first4=H. |last5=Şengül |first5=M. |last6=Adıgüzel |first6=A. |last7=Öztürk |first7=S. |last8=Kotan |first8=R. |journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology |volume=87 |issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pages=411–416 |doi=10.2478/s11535-009-0027-z |title=Chemical composition and antimicrobial activity of Satureja hortensis L. essential oil |year=2009 |last1=Mihajilov-Krstev |first1=T. |last2=Radnović |first2=D. |last3=Kitić |first3=D. |last4=Zlatković |first4=B. |last5=Ristić |first5=M. |last6=Branković |first6=S. |journal=Central European Journal of Biology |volume=4 |issue=3}}</ref> | [[File:Satureja hortensis Prague 2011 1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Sceletium tortuosum]]'' | Kanna | African treatment for depression. Suggested to be an SSRI or have similar effects, but unknown mechanism of activity. | [[File:Kanna flower.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Senna auriculata]]'' | Avaram senna | The root is used in [[decoction]]s against [[fevers]], [[diabetes]], diseases of [[urinary system]] and [[constipation]]. The leaves have [[laxative]] properties. The dried flowers and flower buds are used as a substitute for tea in case of [[diabetes]] patients. The powdered seed is also applied to the eye, in case of chronic purulent [[conjunctivitis]]. | [[File:(Senna auriculata) at kambalakonda 01.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Sesuvium portulacastrum]]'' | Shoreline purslane | The plant extract showed [[antibacterial]] and anticandidal activities and moderate [[antifungal]] activity.<ref>Chandrasekaran M., Senthilkumar A., Venkatesalu V "Antibacterial and antifungal efficacy of fatty acid methyl esters from the leaves of Sesuvium portulacastrum L. ". European Review for Medical and Pharmacological Sciences. 15 (7) (pp 775-780), 2011.</ref> | [[File:Starr 080602-5547 Sesuvium portulacastrum.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Silybum marianum]]'' | [[Milk thistle]] | It has been used for thousands of years for a variety of medicinal purposes, in particular [[liver disease|liver problems]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/milkthistle/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405072302/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/milkthistle/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Milk thistle flowerhead.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Stachytarpheta cayennensis]]'' | Blue snakeweed | Extracts of the plant are used to ease the symptoms of [[malaria]]. The boiled juice or a tea made from the leaves or the whole plant is taken to relieve [[fever]] and other symptoms. It is also used for [[dysentery]], [[pain]], and [[liver]] disorders.<ref name=froe>{{cite journal | author = Froelich S. ''et al.'' | year = 2008 | title = Phenylethanoid glycosides from ''Stachytarpheta cayennensis'' (Rich.) Vahl, Verbenaceae, a traditional antimalarial medicinal plant | url = http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0102-695X2008000400003&script=sci_arttext | journal = Revista Brasileira de Farmacognosia | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 517–20 | doi = 10.1590/s0102-695x2008000400003 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180418225951/http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0102-695X2008000400003 | archivedate = 2018-04-18 | df = }}</ref> A tea of the leaves is taken to help control [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] in [[Peru]] and other areas.<ref name=ade>{{cite journal | author = Adebajo A. C. ''et al.'' | year = 2007 | title = Hypoglycaemic constituents of ''Stachytarpheta cayennensis'' leaf | url = | journal = Planta Med | volume = 73 | issue = 3| pages = 241–50 | pmid = 17318784 | doi=10.1055/s-2007-967125}}</ref> Laboratory tests indicate that the plant has [[anti-inflammatory]] properties.<ref name=sch>{{cite journal | author = Schapoval E. E. ''et al.'' | year = 1998 | title = ''Antiinflammatory and antinociceptive activities of extracts and isolated compounds from ''Stachytarpheta cayennensis | url = | journal = J Ethnopharmacol | volume = 60 | issue = 1| pages = 53–9 | pmid = 9533432 | doi=10.1016/s0378-8741(97)00136-0}}</ref> | [[File:Blue Snakeweed (2095033321).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Stellaria media]]'' | Common chickweed | It has been used as a remedy to treat itchy skin conditions and [[pulmonary diseases]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Hensel|first=Wolfgang|title=Medicinal plants of Britain and Europe|year=2008|publisher=A&C Black|location=London|isbn=9781408101544}}</ref> 17th century herbalist [[John Gerard]] recommended it as a remedy for [[mange]]. Modern [[herbalist]]s prescribe it for iron-deficiency anemia (for its high iron content), as well as for [[skin disease]]s, [[bronchitis]], [[rheumatic]] pains, [[arthritis]] and [[period pain]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://hartonweb.com/nsp-herbs/goodhealthherbs.com/?sn=220-2 | title = Chickweed | last = Wiest | first = Renee | website = hartonweb.com | publisher = Good Health Herbs | access-date = 15 Dec 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222091238/http://hartonweb.com/nsp-herbs/goodhealthherbs.com/?sn=220-2 | archivedate = 2015-12-22 | df = }}</ref> | [[File:Kaldari Stellaria media 01.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Strobilanthes callosus]]'' | Karvy | The plant is [[anti-inflammatory]], [[antimicrobial]],<ref name="Anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities of triterpenoids from Strobilanthes callosus Nees">Singh, B.; Sahu, P.M.; Sharma, M.K. (2002, May 1). [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Anti-inflammatory+and+antimicrobial+activities+of+triterpenoids+from...-a092527805 Anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities of triterpenoids from Strobilanthes callosus Nees. (Short Communication)] The Free Library. (2002). Retrieved January 21, 2010</ref> and anti-rheumatic.<ref name="Anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic activities of lupeol and 19α-H lupeol isolated from Strobilanthus callosus and Strobilanthus ixiocephala roots.">Agarwal R., Rangari V. [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:-2sD5rU9LZAJ:medind.nic.in/ibi/t03/i6/ibit03i6p384.pdf+Strobilanthes+callosus&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESiNhDe-JqZLmk1JeIFeO_1Y-1CuqR9OUctyCSA-R29-VhcVvirhAP_Hc2RoNqydoBp1HZ-KJRgHPK6eNHwzBh8x4lXiFLzQOn71Agfmwmgtm3NtEwsmz9n9FHipB9nuOdd0YybQ&sig=AHIEtbT3ZyKZpmmFAG9TNc8CNiTvLwUIqA Anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic activities of lupeol and 19α-H lupeol isolated from Strobilanthus callosus and Strobilanthus ixiocephala roots.] Ind. J. Pharm. 2003;35:384–387. Pdf: {{cite web |url=http://medind.nic.in/ibi/t03/i6/ibit03i6p384.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511140829/http://medind.nic.in/ibi/t03/i6/ibit03i6p384.pdf |archivedate=2018-05-11 |df= }}</ref> | [[File:Strobilanthes callosus.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Symphytum officinale]]'' | [[Comfrey]] | It has been used as a [[vulnerary]] and to reduce [[inflammation]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/afcm/comfrey.html |publisher=University of Wisconsin Extension, University of Minnesota Extension |title=Alternative Field Crops Manual |author1=T.M. Teynor |author2=D.H. Putnam |author3=J.D. Doll |author4=K.A. Kelling |author5=E.A. Oelke |author6=D.J. Undersander |author7=E.S. Oplinger |accessdate=2011-10-18 |chapter=Comfrey |year=1997 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110100553/http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/afcm/comfrey.html |archivedate=2011-11-10 |df= }}</ref> It was also used internally in the past, for stomach and other ailments, but its toxicity has led a number of other countries, including Canada, Brazil, Australia, and the United Kingdom, to severely restrict or ban the use of comfrey.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/ntp/htdocs/Chem_Background/ExSumPdf/Comfrey.pdf |title = Comfrey and One of Its Constituent Alkaloids Symphytine, Review of Toxicological Literatur |date = October 2007 |accessdate = 2011-10-18 |author = Raymond Tice |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120401220501/http://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/ntp/htdocs/Chem_Background/ExSumPdf/Comfrey.pdf |archivedate = 2012-04-01 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Symphytum officinale (4970747322).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Syzygium aromaticum]]'' | [[Clove]] | The plant is used for upset stomach and as an [[expectorant]], among other purposes. The [[clove oil|oil]] is used topically to treat [[toothache]].<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/251.html |publisher = [[National Institute of Health]] [[MedlinePlus]] |title = Clove |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160705113542/https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/251.html |archivedate = 2016-07-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Cloves.JPG|200x200px]]
|}
== T ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Tanacetum parthenium]]'' | [[Tanacetum parthenium|Feverfew]] | The plant has been used for centuries for [[fever]]s, [[headache]]s, [[stomach ache]]s, [[toothache]]s, [[insect bite]]s and other conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/feverfew/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Feverfew |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150331184558/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/feverfew |archivedate = 2015-03-31 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Feverfew.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Taraxacum officinale]]'' | [[Dandelion]] | It was most commonly used historically to treat [[liver disease]]s, [[kidney disease]]s, and [[spleen]] problems.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/dandelion/ |title = Dandelion |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527170439/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/dandelion |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Sluníčka Vysočiny.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Teucrium scordium]]'' | Water germander | It has been used for asthma, diarrhea, fever, intestinal parasites, hemorrhoids, and wounds.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-70-WATER+GERMANDER.aspx?activeIngredientId=70&activeIngredientName=WATER+GERMANDER&source=3 |title = Water Germander |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425180745/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-70-WATER+GERMANDER.aspx?activeIngredientId=70&activeIngredientName=WATER+GERMANDER&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Teucrium scordium2 eF.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Thymus vulgaris]]'' | [[Thyme]] | The plant is used to treat [[bronchitis]] and cough. It serves as an [[antispasmodic]] and [[expectorant]] in this role. It has also been used in many other medicinal roles in Asian and Ayurvedic medicine, although it has not been shown to be effective in non-respiratory medicinal roles.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mLYlsMszi64C&lpg=PA535&dq=thyme%20cough&pg=PA535#v=onepage&q=thyme%20cough&f=false | page=535 | title=The PDR Family Guide to Natural Medicines & Healing Therapies | editor=Sifton, David W. | publisher=Random House Digital, Inc. | year=2000 | isbn=978-0-345-43377-0 }}</ref> | [[File:Mouche sur du thym en fleurs à Grez-Doiceau 002.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Tilia cordata]]'' | Small-leaved linden | In the countries of Central, Southern and Western Europe, linden flowers are a traditional herbal remedy made into an herbal tea called [[Herbal and fruit teas|tisane]].<ref name=botanical>{{cite web|last=Grieve|first=M|title=Lime Tree|url=https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/l/limtre28.html|publisher=Botanical.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304025631/https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/l/limtre28.html|archivedate=2014-03-04|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Tilia cordata (2560923908).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Tradescantia zebrina]]'' | Inchplant | It is used in southeast [[Mexico]] in the region of [[Tabasco]] as a cold [[herbal tea]], which is named ''Matali''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.projectnoah.org/spottings/6529291|title=Wandering Jew / Spiderwort|website=Project Noah|access-date=2016-09-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927082021/http://www.projectnoah.org/spottings/6529291|archivedate=2016-09-27|df=}}</ref> [[Contact dermatitis|Skin irritation]] may result from repeated contact with or prolonged handling of the plant, particularly from the clear, watery [[sap]] (a characteristic unique to ''T. zebrina'' as compared with other types). | [[File:Gardenology-IMG 7927 hunt10aug.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Trema orientalis]]'' | Charcoal-tree | The leaves and the bark are used to treat [[cough]]s, [[sore throat]]s, [[asthma]], [[bronchitis]], [[gonorrhea]], [[yellow fever]], [[toothache]], and as an [[antidote]] to general [[poison]]ing.<ref name="FAO-X5327e">{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/X5327e/x5327e1p.htm|title=Trema orientalis|last=Eckman|first=Karlyn|author2=Hines, Deborah A.|date=1993|work=Indigenous multipurpose trees of Tanzania: uses and economic benefits for people|publisher=[[FAO]] Forestry Department|accessdate=2010-03-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616233501/http://www.fao.org/docrep/x5327e/x5327e1p.htm|archivedate=2010-06-16|df=}}</ref> | [[File:Kharagola (Marathi- खरगोळ) (537093835).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Trifolium pratense]]'' | [[Red clover]] | The plant is an ingredient in some recipes for [[essiac]] tea. Research has found no benefit for any human health conditions.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/redclover/ataglance.htm |title = Red clover |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527104053/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/redclover/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Kleebluete.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Trigonella foenum-graecum]]'' | [[Fenugreek]] | It has long been used to treat symptoms of [[menopause]], and digestive ailments. More recently, it has been used to treat [[diabetes]], [[loss of appetite]] and other conditions<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/fenugreek/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Fenugreek |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150330095851/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/fenugreek |archivedate = 2015-03-30 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Aesthetic_bunch_of_fenugreek_greens.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Common wheat|Triticum aestivum]]'' | [[Wheatgrass]] | It may contain antioxidant and anti-inflammatory compounds.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-1073-WHEATGRASS.aspx?activeIngredientId=1073&activeIngredientName=WHEATGRASS&source=3 |title = Wheatgrass |work = WebMD |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150425092414/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-1073-WHEATGRASS.aspx?activeIngredientId=1073&activeIngredientName=WHEATGRASS&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-25 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Blé tendre hiver (GHAYTA) AO-5-cliche Jean Weber (5) (24000515671).jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Turnera subulata]]'' | White buttercup | It is used for skin, gastrointestinal, and respiratory ailments.<ref name=prab>{{cite journal | author = Prabhahar C. ''et al.'' | year = 2012 | title = Studies on the antifungal activity of ''Turnera subulata'' and ''Acacia nilotica'' against pathogenic fungal pathogens | url = http://www.recentscientific.com/sites/default/files/Download_61.pdf | format = PDF | journal = International Journal of Recent Scientific Research | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 149–54 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150715100912/http://www.recentscientific.com/sites/default/files/Download_61.pdf | archivedate = 2015-07-15 | df = }}</ref> Laboratory tests showed it has some inhibitory activity against various [[fungus|fungi]], such as ''[[Candida glabrata]]'', ''[[Aspergillus flavus]]'', ''[[Aspergillus niger|A. niger]]'', ''[[Aspergillus fumigatus|A. fumigatus]]'', ''[[Penicillium chrysogenum]]'', and ''[[Candida albicans]]''.<ref name=prab/>
| [[File:BangbangNuevaVizcayajf9987 14.JPG|200x200px]]
|}
== U ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Uncaria tomentosa]]'' | [[Uncaria tomentosa|Cat's claw]] | It has a long history of use in South America to prevent and treat disease.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/catclaw/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Cat's claw |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405065250/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/catclaw |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Urtica dioica]]'' | Common nettle, stinging nettle | It has been used in the traditional Austrian medicine internally (as tea or fresh leaves) to treat disorders of the kidneys and urinary tract, gastrointestinal tract, locomotor system, skin, cardiovascular system, hemorrhage, influenza, rheumatism, and gout.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vogl|first1=S|last2=Picker|first2=P|last3=Mihaly-Bison|first3=J|last4=Fakhrudin|first4=N|last5=Atanasov|first5=AG|last6=Heiss|first6=EH|last7=Wawrosch|first7=C|last8=Reznicek |first8=G|last9=Dirsch|first9=VM|last10=Saukel|first10=J|last11=Kopp|first11=B|year=2013|title=Ethnopharmacological in vitro studies on Austria's folk medicine - An unexplored lore in vitro anti-inflammatory activities of 71 Austrian traditional herbal drugs|journal=J Ethnopharmacol|volume=149|pages=750–71|doi=10.1016/j.jep.2013.06.007|pmid=23770053|pmc=3791396}}</ref> | [[File:20120623 Brennnesseln Hockenheim 3.jpg|200x200px]]
|}
== V ==
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! width=200px | Scientific name ! width=200px | Name ! width=400px | Description ! Picture
|- | ''[[Vaccinium]]'' spec. | [[Blueberries]] | They are of current medical interest as an [[antioxidant]]<ref>{{cite journal |pages=2686–93 |doi=10.1021/jf980145d |title=Antioxidant Capacity As Influenced by Total Phenolic and Anthocyanin Content, Maturity, and Variety ofVacciniumSpecies |year=1998 |last1=Prior |first1=Ronald L. |last2=Cao |first2=Guohua |last3=Martin |first3=Antonio |last4=Sofic |first4=Emin |last5=McEwen |first5=John |last6=O'Brien |first6=Christine |last7=Lischner |first7=Neal |last8=Ehlenfeldt |first8=Mark |last9=Kalt |first9=Willy | displayauthors = 8|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry |volume=46 |issue=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | journal=Journal of Food Science | title=Bioactive Properties of Wild Blueberry Fruits | volume=65 | issue=2 | year=2000 |author1=M.A.L. Smith |author2=K.A. Marley |author3=D. Seigler |author4=K.W. Singletary |author5=B. Meline | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2621.2000.tb16006.x | pages=352–356 }}</ref> and for [[urinary tract]] ailments.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1056/NEJM199810083391516 |title=Inhibition of the Adherence of P-FimbriatedEscherichia colito Uroepithelial-Cell Surfaces by Proanthocyanidin Extracts from Cranberries |year=1998 |last1=Howell |first1=Amy B. |last2=Vorsa |first2=Nicholi |last3=Marderosian |first3=Ara Der |last4=Foo |first4=Lai Yeap |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=339 |issue=15 |pages=1085–6 |pmid=9767006}}</ref> | [[File:Vaccinium.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Vaccinium macrocarpon]]'' | [[Cranberry]] | It was used historically as a [[vulnerary]] and for urinary disorders, [[diarrhea]], [[diabetes]], stomach ailments, and [[liver disease|liver problems]]. Modern usage has concentrated on [[urinary tract]] related problems.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/cranberry/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Cranberry |accessdate = 2011-09-30 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> | [[File:Cranberry bog.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Vaccinium myrtillus]]'' | [[Bilberry]] | It is used to treat [[diarrhea]], [[scurvy]], and other conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/bilberry/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Bilberry |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405043702/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/bilberry |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Bilberry.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Valeriana officinalis]]'' | [[Valerian (herb)|Valerian]] | It has been used since at least [[ancient Greece]] and [[ancient Rome|Rome]] for [[insomnia|sleep disorders]] and [[anxiety]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/valerian/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Valerian |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405075559/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/valerian |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Valeriana officinalis02.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Verbascum thapsus]]'' | Common mullein | It contains [[glycyrrhizin]] compounds with [[bactericide]] and potential anti-[[tumor]]al action. These compounds are concentrated in the flowers.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Turker|first=Arzu Ucar |author2=N. D. Camper | title=Biological activity of common mullein, a medicinal plant|journal= Journal of Ethnopharmacology |date=October 2002| volume=82| issue=2–3| pages=117–125 | doi=10.1016/S0378-8741(02)00186-1| pmid=12241986}}</ref> | [[File:20150930Verbascum thapsus2.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Verbena officinalis]]'' | [[Verbena]] | It is used for sore throats and respiratory tract diseases.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-88-VERBENA.aspx?activeIngredientId=88&activeIngredientName=VERBENA&source=3 |publisher = WebMD |title = Verbena |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150427070555/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-88-VERBENA.aspx?activeIngredientId=88&activeIngredientName=VERBENA&source=3 |archivedate = 2015-04-27 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:20140807Verbena officinalis2.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Vernonia amygdalina]]'' | [[Bitter leaf]] | The plant is used by both [[primate]]s and indigenous peoples in Africa to treat intestinal ailments such as [[dysentery]].<ref name="wynn">{{Cite book |title=Veterinary herbal medicine |author1=Susan G. Wynn |author2=Barbara Fougère |chapter=Zoopharmacognosy |publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-323-02998-8 |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref><ref name="huffman">{{cite journal | author=Huffman, M.A., Seifu, M | title=Observations on the illness and consumption of a possibly medicinal plant Vernonia amygdalina (Del.), by a wild chimpanzee in the Mahale Mountains National Park, Tanzania | journal=Primates | year=1989 | volume=30 | pages=51–63 | doi=10.1007/BF02381210 }}</ref> | |- | ''[[Veronica officinalis]]'' | Veronica | The plant is used for sinus and ear infections.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-135-VERONICA.aspx?activeIngredientId=135&activeIngredientName=VERONICA&source=3 |publisher = WebMD |title = Veronica |accessdate = 2015-04-06 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304094426/http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-135-VERONICA.aspx?activeIngredientId=135&activeIngredientName=VERONICA&source=3 |archivedate = 2016-03-04 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Veronica officinalis 5499177.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Viburnum tinus]]'' | Laurustinus | ''V. tinus'' has medicinal properties. The active ingredients are [[viburnin]] (a substance or more probably a mixture of compounds) and tannins. Tannins can cause stomach upset. The leaves when infused have [[antipyretic]] properties. The fruits have been used as purgatives against constipation. The tincture has been used lately in herbal medicine as a remedy for depression. The plant also contains [[iridoid]] [[glucoside]]s.<ref>Iridoid glucosides from Viburnum tinus. Lamberto Tomassini, M. Francesca Cometa, Sebastiano Foddai and Marcello Nicoletti, Phytochemistry, January 1995, Volume 38, Issue 2, Pages 423–425, {{doi|10.1016/0031-9422(94)00618-4}}</ref> | [[File:Viburnum February 2008-1.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Viola tricolor]]'' | Wild pansy | It is one of many viola plant species containing [[cyclotides]]. These small [[peptides]] have proven to be useful in drug development due to their size and structure giving rise to high stability. Many cyclotides, found in ''Viola tricolor'' are [[cytotoxic]].<ref>Tang J., Wang C.K., Pan X., Yan H., Zeng G., Xu W., He W., Daly N.L., Craik D.J., Tan N."Isolation and characterization of cytotoxic cyclotides from Viola tricolor" Peptides 2010 31:8 (1434-1440)</ref> This feature means that it could be used to treat [[cancers]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Svangård Erika, Göransson Ulf, Hocaoglu Zozan, Gullbo Joachim, Larsson Rolf, Claeson Per, Bohlin Lars | year = 2004 | title = Cytotoxic Cyclotides from Viola tricolor | url = | journal = Journal of Natural Products | volume = 67 | issue = 2| pages = 144–147 | doi=10.1021/np030101l}}</ref><ref>Tang J., Wang C.K., Pan X., Yan H., Zeng G., Xu W., He W., Daly N.L., Craik D.J., Tan N. ,"Isolation and characterization of cytotoxic cyclotides from Viola tricolor", ''Peptides'' 2010; 31:8 1434-1440</ref>
| [[File:Viola tricolor, Schenley Park, 2015-10-01, 01.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Viscum album]]'' | [[European mistletoe]] | It has been used to treat seizures, headaches, and other conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/mistletoe/ |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Mistletoe |accessdate = 2011-10-04 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405070000/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/mistletoe |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Viscum album fruit.jpg|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Vitex agnus-castus]]'' | [[Chasteberry]] | It has been used for over thousands of years for menstrual problems, and to stimulate [[lactation]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/chasteberry |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Chasteberry |accessdate = 2011-09-30 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150405044356/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/chasteberry |archivedate = 2015-04-05 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Vitex agnus-castus.JPG|200x200px]]
|- | ''[[Vitis vinifera]]'' | [[Grape]] | The leaves and fruit have been used medicinally since the [[ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nccih.nih.gov/health/grapeseed/ataglance.htm |publisher = [[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]] |title = Grape seed |accessdate = 2011-10-13 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150326163215/https://nccih.nih.gov/health/grapeseed/ataglance.htm |archivedate = 2015-03-26 |df = }}</ref> | [[File:Grape vines 2015 02.jpg|200x200px]]
|}

M. | last5 = Palazón | first5 = J. | title = Steroidal Lactones from Withania somnifera, an Ancient Plant for Novel Medicine | doi = 10.3390/molecules14072373 | journal = Molecules | volume = 14 | issue = 7 | pages = 2373–2393 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19633611 | pmc = }}</ref> | [[File:Withania somnifera 06.jpg|200x200px]]

[[File:Mary E. McDowell 154006v.jpg|right|thumb|Mary E. McDowell, University of Chicago Settlement, Stock-Yards District, 1900-1916]] {{About|the social reformer|the telecommunications executive|Mary T. McDowell}}
'''Mary Eliza McDowell''' (November 30, 1854 –1936) was an American [[Reform movement|social reformer]] and prominent figure in the [[Chicago]] [[Settlement movement]].
== Early life == Mary Eliza McDowell was born on November 30, 1854 to Malcolm and Jane Welch Gordon McDowell in [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]] as the oldest of six children. Her father was recognized for his distinguished service in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] and support for the presidency helped to establish her political conviction. After the war, the family left for [[Chicago]] where her father opened and managed a steel rolling mill and the family joined the [[Methodism|Methodist]] Church. The changes led her mother to become an invalid, no longer able to care for the family, and McDowell became responsible for her five brothers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = American Social Leaders and Activists|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tKxOpAh78IsC|publisher = Infobase Publishing|date = 2014-05-14|isbn = 9781438108087|language = en|first = Neil A.|last = Hamilton}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = A Consuming Faith: The Social Gospel and Modern American Culture|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qmgIzBotLagC|publisher = University of Missouri Press|date = 2001-01-01|isbn = 9780826213624|language = en|first = Susan|last = Curtis}}</ref>
In the family’s first few years in Chicago, McDowell was involved in various relief efforts and religious involvement. During the [[Great Chicago Fire]] in 1871, McDowell and her father worked to help refugees by transporting people and their belongings to the makeshift camp away from the fire. When aid was received from Ohio, McDowell took the lead in the relief effort and was later recognized by [[Rutherford B. Hayes|President Rutherford B. Hayes]] for her service. She later organized religious classes for young people that attracted prominent figures in the [[temperance movement]], students from [[Northwestern University]], and residents of Chicago.<ref name=":0" />
== Career == McDowell first began work for Frances Williard, founder of the Women’s Christian Temperance Movement, where she met [[Elizabeth Harrison (educator)|Elizabeth Harrison]]. With Harrison's support, McDowell started teaching kindergarten classes at the [[Hull House]] and helped to organize the women’s club under [[Jane Addams]] and [[Ellen Gates Starr|Ellen Gates Star]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = McDowell|url = http://www.chicagotribute.org/Markers/McDowell.htm|website = www.chicagotribute.org|access-date = 2016-01-22}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Midwestern Women: Work, Community, and Leadership at the Crossroads|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Z2ODrLBzquoC|publisher = Indiana University Press|date = 1997-01-01|isbn = 0253211336|language = en|first = Lucy Eldersveld|last = Murphy|first2 = Wendy Hamand|last2 = Venet}}</ref>
In 1893, The [[University of Chicago]] was in its second year of existence and wanted to start an initiative to become involved in the city and looked to the Settlement movement to do so. Working with the university’s Christian Union, Jane Addams, and Professor J. Laurence Laughlin, the university established the University of Chicago Settlement House in the Stock Yard District on January 1, 1894 at 4688 South Gross Avenue. Under Addams’ recommendation, they hired McDowell to head a larger [[New City, Chicago|Back of the Yards]] settlement house.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Polish Immigrants and Industrial Chicago: Workers on the South Side, 1880-1922|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pSPzsIKMO44C|publisher = University of Chicago Press|date = 1991-01-01|isbn = 9780226644240|language = en|first = Dominic A.|last = Pacyga}}</ref> Under her leadership, McDowell worked with residents of the stockyard to improve their neighborhood though education of politic rights and civic consciousness. A major initiative she headed early on was the establishment of civic clubs for both men and women.<ref name=":2" />
In 1894, McDowell opened the University of Chicago Settlement House to alleviate the crowded, unsanitary housing immigrant families often faced. There, she organized classes, provided kindergarten education and accesses to vocational schools, bathing facilities, concerts, lectures, and clubs.<ref name=":1" />
She lobbied the U.S. government to establish the [[United States Women's Bureau|Women’s Bureau]] to study living and working conditions of women and children.<ref name=":1" />
==See also== *[[Settlement movement]]

'''The NGC Bocas Lit Fest''' is the [[Trinidad and Tobago]] literary festival that takes place annually during the last weekend of April in [[Port of Spain]]. Inaugurated in 2011,<ref>[http://repeatingislands.com/2011/02/07/the-bocas-lit-fest-the-trinidad-and-tobago-literary-festival/ "The Bocas Lit Fest: The Trinidad and Tobago Literary Festival"], ''Repeating Islands'', February 2011.</ref> it is the first major literary festival in the [[southern Caribbean]]<ref>[http://sta.uwi.edu/uwitoday/archive/april_2011/article13.asp "3 shortlisted for Bocas Prize"], ''UWI Today'', University of the West Indies, St Augustine, April 2011.</ref> and largest literary festival in the [[Anglophone Caribbean]].<ref>[http://tunuptv.com/ngc-bocas-lit-fest-debateon-tv6-today/ "NGC Bocas Lit Fest Debate on TV6 today"], ''[[Trinidad Express Newspapers]]'', 22 April 2012.</ref><ref>[[Carolyn Cooper]], [http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20110508/cleisure/cleisure3.html "T&T Lit Fest Puts Us to Shame"], ''[[Jamaica Gleaner]]'', 8 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://tunuptv.com/2012/04/23/ngc-bocas-lit-fest-debateon-tv6-today/ "NGC Bocas Lit Fest Debate on TV6 today"], Tun Up TV.</ref> A registered non-profit company, the festival has as its title sponsor the [[National Gas Company of Trinidad and Tobago]] (NGC).<ref>Iana Seales, [http://www.newsday.co.tt/features/0,208521.html "Lit Fest opens up to non-English writers"], ''[[Trinidad and Tobago Newsday]]'', 19 March 2015.</ref> Other sponsors and partners include [[First Citizens Bank (Trinidad and Tobago)|First Citizens Bank]], [[One Caribbean Media]] (OCM), who sponsor the associated [[OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature]], CODE (sponsors of the Burt Award), and the [[Commonwealth Foundation]].<ref>[http://looptt.com/2015/03/19/ngc-bocas-lit-fest-launched-nalis/ "NGC Bocas Lit Fest launched at NALIS"], ''Loop'', 19 March 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/sponsors/ "Our Sponsors"], NGC Bocas Lit Fest.</ref>
The NGC Bocas Lit Fest also works in collaboration with other international festivals and initiatives, and has hosted events showcasing Caribbean writing talent in New York,<ref>Mark Fraser, [http://www.trinidadexpress.com/sunday-mix/Bocas-goes-to-Harlem-265870661.html "Bocas goes to Harlem! TT’s literary festival joins fiction programme in New York City"], ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 4 July 2014.</ref> at the Brooklyn Book Fair,<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/2013/bocas-at-the-brooklyn-book-fest/ "Bocas at the Brooklyn Book Fest"], 2013. NGC Bocas Lit Fest website.</ref><ref>Johnny Temple [http://caribbean-beat.com/issue-117/word-mouth#axzz3MAG25Gjq "Bookish in Brooklyn"] (on the Caribbean element in the Brooklyn Book Festival). Word of Mouth, ''Caribbean Beat'', Issue 117, September/October 2012.</ref> the [[Harlem Book Fair]]<ref>[http://www.harlembookfair.com/#!world-fiction-at-columbia-university/c8e1 "Coming from Far: Caribbean Writers on Home and Otherness (Readings and Discussion)"]. Presented by the NGC Bocas Literary Festival. Harlem Book Fair 2014.</ref><ref>Ivette Romero, [http://repeatingislands.com/2014/07/05/bocas-goes-to-harlem/ "Bocas Goes to Harlem"], Repeating Islands, 5 July 2014.</ref> and elsewhere in the US. In 2012, Bocas partnered with the Edinburgh World Writers Conference (EWWC) as part of a lineup of 14 countries delivering a multinational series of talks marking the 50th anniversary of the five-day meeting of "an impressive, sensational and sometimes scandalous group of writers" at the first [[Edinburgh International Festival|Edinburgh International Festival of Music and Drama]].<ref>[http://www.trinidadexpress.com/sunday-mix/WORLD_WRITERS_AT_BOCAS-196799601.html "World Writers at Bocas"], ''Trinidad Express newspapers'', 10 March 2013.</ref> The Bocas Lit Fest was described by Claire Armitstead of ''[[The Guardian]]'' as "expansive in its cultural reach, reflecting a region that has responded to its own colonisation over the centuries by seeding its people to every continent".<ref>Claire Armitstead, [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/05/marlon-james-makes-heros-return-to-the-caribbean-at-bocas-festival "Marlon James makes hero's return to the Caribbean at Bocas festival"], ''The Guardian'', 5 May 2016.</ref>
==Background== The Bocas Lit Fest organising team comprises [[Marina Salandy-Brown]], founder and director; programme director [[Nicholas Laughlin]],<ref>[http://nicholaslaughlin.net/ Nicholas Laughlin's website.]</ref> editor of the ''[[Caribbean Review of Books]]'' and of ''[[Caribbean Beat]]''; [[Funso Aiyejina]], prize-winning author and dean of the Faculty of Humanities and Education at the [[University of the West Indies, St. Augustine]]; [[Marjorie Thorpe]], former professor of literature at the University of the West Indies, St. Augustine, independent bookseller Joan Dayal of Paper Based Bookshop;<ref>[http://paperbased.org/ Paper Based Bookshop website.]</ref><ref>Aneka Lee, [http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2014-04-30/paper-based-normandie-bibliophile%E2%80%99s-hidden-dream "Paper Based at The Normandie a bibliophile’s hidden dream"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 30 April 2014.</ref> Danielle Delon, editor of ''The Letters of Margaret Mann''; local businesswoman Lucita Esau; and Patrice Matthews, a marketing and media professional.<ref name=bocaslitfest>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/about/ About the NGC Bocas Lit Fest.]</ref>
The festival's name derives from the Spanish word for mouth, ''boca'' – the organ of speech and song and storytelling – while also referencing the [[Bocas del Dragón]] (the Dragon's Mouths), which are the narrow straits off Trinidad’s north-west peninsula that connect the [[Gulf of Paria]] to the [[Caribbean Sea]]. For centuries, the Bocas were the gateways connecting Trinidad to the Caribbean and the [[Atlantic Ocean]].
The festival's strapline is: "Celebrating books, writers, and writing from the Caribbean and the rest of the world".
The main venues are the [[National Library of Trinidad and Tobago|National Library]] (NALIS)<ref>Annie Paul, [http://anniepaul.net/2011/05/07/the-bocas-lit-fest-2011/ "The Bocas Lit Fest 2011"], Active Voice, 7 May 2011.</ref> and the Old Fire Station, in downtown [[Port of Spain]],<ref>Marina Salandy-Brown, [http://www.newsday.co.tt/commentary/0,159128.html "What’s in a festival"], ''Newsday'', 26 April 2012.</ref> with satellite evening events at venues around the city.
There is also a full programme of activities for young readers, sponsored by [[KFC]], and in the run-up to the festival storytelling events take place in [[Tobago]], [[Couva]], [[Chaguanas]], [[San Fernando, Trinidad and Tobago|San Fernando]], [[Point Fortin]], [[Mayaro, Trinidad|Mayaro]] and [[Arima]].
===History=== The Bocas Lit Fest was held for the first time in 2011 – from Thursday, 28 April to Sunday, 1 May<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/2011/2011-bocas-lit-fest-programme-announced/ "2011 Bocas Lit Fest programme announced".]</ref> – including readings, panel discussions, workshops, film screenings and art exhibitions.<ref>[http://signifyinguyana.typepad.com/signifyin_guyana/2011/03/trinidad-and-tobagos-bocas-literary-festival-ready-set.html "Trinidad and Tobago's Bocas Literary Festival: Ready, set!"], signifyinguyana.com, 24 March 2011.</ref> Attracting 3,500 attendances over the four days.<ref>A. J. Theolade, [http://www.guardian.co.tt/entertainment/2014-04-23/bocas-lit-fest-continues-blossom "Bocas Lit Fest continues to blossom"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 23 April 2014.</ref> the festival reflected its founder's aims "to promote literature and publishing in Trinidad and Tobago and the need for Caribbean writing to be celebrated everywhere".<ref>[http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Bocas_Lit_Fest_a_hit_in_London-124527658.html "Bocas Lit Fest a hit in London"], ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 24 June 2011.</ref>
The scores of writers taking part in the 2012 festival, both locally based and from abroad,<ref>Julien Neaves, [http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Literary_meals_at_Bocas_Lit_Fest-149177825.html "Literary meals at Bocas Lit Fest"], ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 26 April 2012.</ref> included [[Fred D'Aguiar]], [[Earl Lovelace]], [[Vahni Capildeo]], [[Chika Unigwe]], [[Monique Roffey]], [[Kenneth Ramchand]], [[Mervyn Morris]], [[Achy Obejas]], [[Rabindranath Maharaj]], [[George Lamming]], professor of genetics [[Steve Jones (biologist)|Steve Jones]], [[Merle Hodge]], [[Rahul Bhattacharya]], and [[Michael Anthony (author)|Michael Anthony]]. The festival featured readings, discussions, performances, workshops, screenings of films based on Caribbean writing and music.<ref>Cherisse Moe, [https://guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2012-04-25/bocas-lit-fest-showcase-creative-talent "Bocas Lit Fest to showcase creative talent"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 26 April 2012.</ref>
In 2013, the South+Central NGC Bocas Lit Fest, scheduled to take place annually in November, was inaugurated.<ref>Shivanee Ramlochan, [http://www.bocaslitfest.com/2014/the-ngc-bocas-lit-fests-southcentral-weekend-part-one/ "The NGC Bocas Lit Fest’s South+Central Weekend".]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2013-10-24/ngc-bocas-lit-fest-goes-south-central "NGC Bocas Lit Fest goes south, central"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 25 October 2013.</ref> In November 2014, NGC Bocas Lit Fest South was hosted by Southern Academy for the Performing Arts (SAPA) in San Fernando, birthplace of the writer [[Sam Selvon]], and the festival commemorated the 20th anniversary of his death.<ref>Shivanee Ramlochan, [http://m.guardian.co.tt/arts/2014-11-16/bocas-south-grows "Bocas South grows"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 16 November 2014.</ref>
In 2014, "Festival Radio" was inaugurated, to "bring the festival experience to listeners around the globe",<ref>[http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/NGC-Bocas-Lit-Fest-makes-radio-debut-256271031.html "NGC Bocas Lit Fest makes radio debut"], ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 22 April 2014.</ref> as well as attracting "a lot of attention on social media, spurred on in part by the active new media presence of the festival itself".<ref>Matthew Hunte, [http://globalvoicesonline.org/2014/05/02/bocas-literary-festival-showcases-caribbean-literature/ "Bocas Literary Festival Showcases Caribbean Literature"], Global Voices, 2 May 2014.</ref>
==Recognition== In February 2017 the Bocas Lit Fest was named as one of "the world’s very best literary events" in a list of "20 Best Literary Festivals Around the World That You Should Attend" chosen by [[Penguin Random House]] - The Writers' Academy, alongside other prestigious festivals including [[Hay Festival|Hay]], [[Edinburgh Book Festival|Edinburgh]] and [[Jaipur Literature Festival|Jaipur]].<ref>[http://www.thewritersacademy.co.uk/blog/literary-festivals/ "20 Best Literary Festivals Around the World That You Should Attend"], The Writers' Academy, Penguin Random House, 10 February 2017.</ref><ref>[http://103fm.tt/?p=20039 "Bocas Lit Fest named among the world’s top literary festivals"], 103fm, 14 February 2017.</ref><ref>[http://ctvtt.com/ctv/index.php/c-news/news/item/46678-bocas-lit-fest-named-among-top-20-literary-festivals-worldwide "Bocas Lit Fest Named Among Top 20 Literary Festivals Worldwide"], C News, 17 February 2017.</ref>
Another accolade, from Jonathan Ford of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' in May 2017, noted: "In the seven years since Bocas launched, Caribbean writers have been heaped with international accolades — the 2015 [[Man Booker Prize for Fiction]], four [[Forward Prizes for Poetry]] between 2014 and 2016, and a slew of [[National Book Awards]]. Virtually all the writers honoured — including [[Marlon James (novelist)|Marlon James]], [[Kei Miller]] and [[Vahni Capildeo]] — were first recognised at this extraordinary little festival in the tropics, a place that is only far away to those who refuse to read."<ref>Jonathan Ford, [https://www.ft.com/content/424a25d4-3f0b-11e7-9d56-25f963e998b2 "Trinidad Diary"], ''Financial Times'', 26 May 2017.</ref>
==Associated initiatives==
===OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature=== {{Main|OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature}}
The centrepiece of the NGC Bocas Lit Fest festival is the announcement at an award ceremony of the overall winner of the OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature.<ref>[http://www.creativecaribbeannetwork.com/person/12135/en "Bocas Lit Fest – The Trinidad and Tobago Literary Festival"], Creative Caribbean Network.</ref> Entries for the prize are in the categories of fiction, non-fiction and poetry for a book by a Caribbean writer published in the previous year, with the overall winner being chosen by a panel of judges from the three genre winners.<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/the-ocm-bocas-prize-for-caribbean-literature/ "The OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature"] at Bocas Lit Fest website.</ref> The winners have been: in 2011, [[Derek Walcott]]'s poetry collection ''White Egrets'', in 2012 [[Earl Lovelace]]'s novel ''Is Just a Movie'', in 2013 [[Monique Roffey]]'s novel ''Archipelago'', in 2014 [[Robert Antoni]]'s novel ''As Flies to Whatless Boys'', in 2015 [[Vladimir Lucien]]'s ''Sounding Ground'' (poetry), in 2016 [[Olive Senior]]'s ''The Pain Tree'' (fiction), and in 2017 [[Kei Miller]]'s ''[[Augustown]]'' (fiction).<ref>[https://www.bocaslitfest.com/2017/awards/the-ocm-bocas-prize-for-caribbean-literature/ "OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature"] on NGC Bocas Lit Fest website.</ref>
=== The Emerging Caribbean Writers Prize (formerly the Hollick Arvon Caribbean Writers Prize) === The Emerging Caribbean Writers Prize, formerly known as the Hollick Arvon Caribbean Writers Prize, is jointly administered by the Bocas Lit Fest and the creative writing organisation [[Arvon Foundation|Arvon]], and is an award that allows an emerging Caribbean writer living and working in the Caribbean to devote time to developing or finishing a literary work in-progress, with support from an established writer as mentor.<ref name=ECWP>[https://www.bocaslitfest.com/2017/awards/hollick-arvon-prize/ "The Emerging Caribbean Writers Prize"], NGC Bocas Lit Fest.</ref> Sponsored by the Hollick Family Charitable Trust for a period of three years (2013–15), and announced at the Bocas Lit Fest in 2012 by [[Sue Woodford-Hollick, Lady Hollick|Sue Woodford-Hollick]],<ref>[http://news.caribseek.com/index.php/caribbean-islands-news/trinidad-and-tobago-news/item/11264-announcing-the-hollick-arvon-caribbean-writers-prize "Announcing the Hollick Arvon Caribbean Writers Prize"], Caribseek News, 1 May 2012.</ref> the prize was awarded to writers in three literary genres over consecutive years: fiction in 2013; non-fiction in 2014; and poetry in 2015.<ref>[http://www.newsday.co.tt/features/0,162305.html "New literature prize opens for entries"], ''Newsday'', 25 June 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.tt/arts/2012-08-25/new-prize-seeks-grow-caribbean-writing "New prize seeks to grow Caribbean writing"], ''[[Trinidad & Tobago Guardian]]'', 26 August 2012.</ref> The first winner in 2013, for fiction, was [[Barbara Jenkins]] of Trinidad & Tobago.<ref>[https://guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2013-07-24/emerging-writers-prize-opens-entries "Emerging writers prize opens for entries"], ''Guardian Media'', 24 July 2013.</ref> The winner in 2014, for non-fiction, was [[Jamaicans|Jamaican]] Diana McCaulay.<ref>Ivette Romero, [http://repeatingislands.com/2014/09/10/the-2015-hollick-arvon-caribbean-writers-prize-deadline-approaching/ "The 2015 Hollick Arvon Caribbean Writers Prize—Deadline Approaching"], ''Repeating Islands'', 10 September 2014.</ref> In 2015, the prize was awarded to poet Danielle Boodoo-Fortuné.<ref name=ECWP />
=== Henry Swanzy Award === The [[Henry Swanzy]] Award for Distinguished Service to Caribbean Letters (named after the influential producer of the [[BBC radio]] programme ''[[Caribbean Voices]]'' that ran from 1943 to 1958) was inaugurated at the 2013 NGC Bocas Lit Fest,<ref name="new awards">Zahra Gordon, [http://www.guardian.co.tt/news/2013-03-21/bocas-lit-fest-adds-new-award "Bocas Lit Fest adds new award"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 21 March 2013.</ref> as an "annual lifetime achievement award to recognise service to Caribbean literature by editors, publishers, critics, broadcasters, and others".<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/henry-swanzy-award/ "Henry Swanzy Award for Distinguished Service to Caribbean Letters"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702024441/http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/henry-swanzy-award/ |date=2 July 2015 }}, NGC Bocas Lit Fest.</ref><ref name="new awards" /> In 2013 the award was made to [[John La Rose]] (posthumously) and Sarah White of [[New Beacon Books]].<ref>Marina Salandy-Brown, [http://newsday.co.tt/commentary/0,176428.html "Swanzy meets La Rose"], ''Trinidad & Tobago Newsday'', 18 April 2013.</ref><ref>Sarah White, [http://www.georgepadmoreinstitute.org/sarahs-backchat-bocas-litfest "Sarah's Backchat from the Bocas Litfest"], [[George Padmore Institute]], 6 June 2013.</ref> In 2014, the award was jointly won by Professors [[Kenneth Ramchand]] and [[Gordon Rohlehr]].<ref>Michaelle Loubon, [http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Lit-Fest-honours-for-2-251130231.html "Lit Fest honours for 2...Ramchand, Rohlehr to get awards"], ''Trinidad Express'', 19 March 2014.</ref> The 2015 recipient was [[Margaret Busby]].<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/2013-henry-swanzy-award/ "The 2015 Bocas Henry Swanzy Award Recipient – Margaret Busby, OBE"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130503032904/http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/2013-henry-swanzy-award/ |date=3 May 2013 }}, Bocas Henry Swanzy Award for Distinguished Service to Caribbean Letters.</ref><ref>[http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Swanzy-Award-for-Margaret-Busby-300605741.html "Swanzy Award for Margaret Busby"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150422212954/http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Swanzy-Award-for-Margaret-Busby-300605741.html |date=22 April 2015 }}, ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 19 April 2015.</ref><ref>Shereen Ali, [http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2015-04-29/sharing-our-voices "Sharing Our Voices"], ''Trinidad Guardian'', 29 April 2015.</ref> The 2016 award went to Jeremy Poynting of [[Peepal Tree Press]].<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/2016/bocas-swanzy-award-honour-publisher-jeremy-poynting/ "Bocas Swanzy Award To Honour Publisher Jeremy Poynting"], Bocas Lit Fest, 16 March 2016.</ref><ref>[http://www2.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2016-04-21/all-aboard-bocas-lit-fest "All aboard for Bocas Lit Fest"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 21 April 2016.</ref> In 2017 the award went to Paperbased Book Store owner Joan Dayal.<ref>Shereen Ali, [http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2017-03-23/bocas-lit-fest-gives-henry-swanzy-award-joan-dayal "Bocas Lit Fest gives Henry Swanzy Award to Joan Dayal"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 23 March 2017.</ref>
=== Burt Award for Caribbean Literature === The Bocas Lit Fest additionally administers the Burt Award sponsored by CODE (Canadian Organization for Development Through Education)<ref>[http://www.codecan.org/burt-award-caribbean "Burt Award for Caribbean Literature"] at CODE.</ref> for Caribbean authors of literature for young adults, launched in 2013.<ref name="new awards" />
The first-place winner in 2014 was A-dZiko Gegele, in second place was Joanne Hillhouse and in third place Colleen Smith-Dennis.<ref>[http://www.codecan.org/burt-award-caribbean/meet-winners 2013 Burt Award for Caribbean Literature Winners], CODE.</ref><ref>[http://arcthemagazine.com/arc/2014/04/burt-award-for-caribbean-literature-winners-announced/ "Burt Award for Caribbean Literature Winners Announced"], ''ARC magazine'', 27 April 2014.</ref> In 2015, first prize went to Imam Baksh. In second place was Diana McCaulay and third was [[Lynn Joseph]].<ref>[http://arcthemagazine.com/arc/2015/05/guyanese-author-imam-baksh-wins-codes-2015-burt-award-for-caribbean-literature-first-prize/ "Guyanese Author Imam Baksh wins CODE's 2015 Burt Award for Caribbean Literature first prize"], ''ARC magazine'', 11 May 2015.</ref> The 2016 prize winner was debut novelist Tamika Gibson, with Florenz Webbe Maxwell of Bermuda second, and Danielle Y. C. McClean in third place.<ref>[http://arcthemagazine.com/arc/2016/05/tamika-gibson-wins-codes-2016-burt-award-for-caribbean-literature/ "Tamika Gibson wins CODE’s 2016 Burt Award For Caribbean Literature"], ''ARC magazine'', 9 May 2016.</ref> The 2017 winner was Viviana Prado-Núñez (Puerto Rico/USA), with Kevin Jared Hosein (Trinidad & Tobago) as runner-up, and Lisa Allen-Agostini (Trinidad & Tobago) in third place.<ref>[https://www.burtaward.org/news/winners-of-codes-2017-burt-award-for-caribbean-literature-announced "Winners of CODE' 2017 Burt Award for Caribbean Literature Announced"], Burt Literary Awards, 27 April 2017.</ref>
=== Caribbean Literature Action Group (CALAG) === Launched in 2012<ref>[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/2012/announcing-the-caribbean-literature-action-group/ "Announcing the Caribbean Literature Action Group], NGC Bocas Lit Fest.</ref> was the Caribbean Literature Action Group (CALAG),<ref>[http://www.cariblit.org/about.html "About Us"], Caribbean Literature Action Group.</ref> a new partnership between the NGC Bocas Lit Fest, the [[British Council]],<ref>[http://literature.britishcouncil.org/projects/2013/cariblit "Cariblit"], British Council - Literature.</ref> and [[Commonwealth Writers]], aimed at supporting the development of Caribbean writing and publishing.<!--dead link<ref>[http://www.commonwealthwriters.org/british-council-commonwealth-writers-and-ngc-bocas-lit-fest-announce-new-partnership/ "Commonwealth Writers, British Council and Bocas Lit Fest launch CALAG"], [[Commonwealth Writers]], 6 March 2012.</ref>--><ref>[http://www.britishcouncil.org/press/commonwealth-writers-and-ngc-bocas-lit-fest-new-partnership "British Council, Commonwealth Writers and NGC Bocas Lit Fest announce new partnership"], [[British Council]], 6 March 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2012-03-05/new-partnership-formed-support-caribbean-literary-scene "New partnership formed to support Caribbean literary scene"], ''Trinidad and Tobago Guardian'', 6 March 2012.</ref> Public initiatives of the project use the "CaribLit" brand.<ref>[http://www.cariblit.org/about.html "About Us"], CaribLit – Caribbean Literature Action Group.</ref>
==See also== * [[OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Literature]] <!--* Hollick Arvon Caribbean Writers Prize * Henry Swanzy Award for Distinguished Service to Caribbean Letters * Burt Award for Caribbean Literature-->

Cudjoe]], [http://www.trinidadandtobagonews.com/blog/?p=11068 "Carrying on the Tradition"], ''Trinidad and Tobago News Blog'', 30 April 2018.

revision.text:
The '''National Security Language Initiative''' is a program introduced by [[United States]] [[United States President|President]] [[George W. Bush]] on January 5, 2006 at the [[U.S. University President's Summit]] to develop the foreign language skills of American [[students]], especially in "critical-need" foreign languages such as [[Arabic]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]], and [[Persian language|Persian]]. The initiative was given $114 million in [[fiscal year]] 2007 and $26.6 million in 2008 to expand programs from [[kindergarten]] level to [[universities]].<ref name=Powell2006>{{Citation|title=National Security Language Initiative |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2006/58733.htm |year=2006 |author=[[Dina Powell|Powell, Dina]] |accessdate=2008-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306151344/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2006/58733.htm |archivedate=March 6, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=BECA2008>{{Citation|title=National Security Language Initiative (NSLI) |url=http://exchanges.state.gov/NSLI/ |year=2008 |author=[[Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=2008-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929044930/http://exchanges.state.gov/NSLI/ |archivedate=September 29, 2008 }}</ref>
==Scope of the program== The initiative is coordinated by the [[State Department]], [[United States Department of Education|Education Department]], [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]] and the [[Director of National Intelligence]].<ref name=USDOE2008>{{Citation|title=National Security Language Initiative (NSLI) - About|url=http://www2.ed.gov/about/inits/ed/competitiveness/nsli/about.html|year=2008|author=[[United States Department of Education]]|accessdate=2011-06-23}}</ref>
The National Security Language Initiative has three broad goals: expand the number of Americans mastering critical need languages and start at a younger age, increase the number of advanced-level speakers of foreign languages, increase the number of foreign language teachers and the resources for them.<ref name=Powell2006 />
==Criticisms== Several college leaders have expressed concern about how large of a role the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] is playing in the initiative and, after the program was announced, the lack of details. <ref>{{Citation|title=Bush Push on ‘Critical’ Foreign Languages|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2006/01/06/foreign|year=2006|journal=[[Inside Higher Ed]]|last1=Capriccioso|first1=Rob|last2=Epstein|first2=David|accessdate=2011-06-23}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Critical Language Scholarship (CLS) Program]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Language education in the United States]] [[Category:Education finance in the United States]] [[Category:United States national security policy]] [[Category:Language policy]] [[Category:United States Department of State]] [[Category:United States Department of Education]] [[Category:United States Department of Defense]]

{{Infobox language |name=Palmyrene |region=[[Palmyra]] |extinct=1st millennium |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Semitic languages|Semitic]] |fam3=[[Central Semitic languages|Central Semitic]] |fam4=[[Northwest Semitic languages|Northwest Semitic]] |fam5=[[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] |fam6=[[Western Aramaic languages|Western]] |isoexception=dialect |linglist=qhy-pal |glotto=none |script=[[Palmyrene alphabet]] }} '''Palmyrene''' or '''Palmyrenean''' was a [[Western Aramaic languages|Western Aramaic]] dialect spoken in the city of [[Palmyra]], [[Syria]], in the early centuries AD. The development of cursive versions of Aramaic led to the creation of the [[Palmyrene alphabet]].
Other West Aramaic dialects include [[Nabataean]] and [[Judeo-Aramaic]]. West Aramaic dialects continue to be spoken in three villages in [[Syria]]: [[Maaloula]], [[Bakh`a]] and [[Jubb`adin]].
==See also== *[[Western Neo-Aramaic]] *[[Palmyrene Empire]] *[[Palmyrene alphabet]]
==Bibliography== *Delbert R. Hillers, Eleonora Cussini, Eleanora Cussini, ''Palmyrene Aramaic Texts'', Johns Hopkins University Press (1996), {{ISBN|978-0-8018-5278-7}} *Hans H. Spoer, "Palmyrene Inscriptions found at Palmyra in April, 1904", ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' (1904) *[[John Swinton (1703–77)|John Swinton]], ''An Explication of All the Inscriptions in the Palmyrene Language and Character Hitherto Publish'd. In Five Letters from the Reverend Mr. John Swinton, M. A. of Christ-Church, Oxford, and F. R. S. to the Reverend Thomas Birch, D. D. Secret. R. S.'', ''[[Philosophical Transactions]]'' (1753).
[[Category:Aramaic languages]] [[Category:Languages of Syria|Palmyrenean]] [[Category:Extinct languages of Asia]]

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/58.84.204.66|58.84.204.66]] to version by Theinstantmatrix. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3454704) (Bot)
revision.text:
[[File:Chulupi (Nivaclé) bag - South American objects in the American Museum of Natural History - DSC06043.JPG|thumb|[[Nivaclé people|Nivaclé]] textile pouch, collection of the [[American Museum of Natural History]]]] [[File:Guampa bombilla.jpg|thumb|Guampa [[bombilla]], for drinking mate]] [[File:Pai Tavytera indian traditional wood carving.JPG|thumb|[[Pai Tavytera people|Pai Tavytera]] traditional woodcarving, [[Amambay Department]], 2008]] '''Paraguayan Indian art''' is the visual art created by the [[indigenous peoples of Paraguay]]. While indigenous artists embrace contemporary Western art media, their arts also include [[pre-Columbian]] art forms. Indian art of aboriginal origin includes ceramics, baskets, weaving and threading, feather art and leather work. Indian art of a hybrid nature includes the embroideries, lace, woodcarving and different metal products. [[Paraguay]] is particularly known for its indigenous featherwork and [[basket weaving]].<ref name=para>[http://country.paraguay.com/arts_and_culture/indigenous_art.php "Indigenous art."] ''Paraguay.com'' (retrieved 13 July 2011)</ref>
==Handmade products== The handmade products of Paraguay are of a great variety and comprise ceramic articles, as well as embroideries and sewn articles, as well as wood, baskets, leather work and silver work. Pre-Columbian ceramics made in the Paraguayan territory were rustic and made from terracotta clay. They were painted in red, and occasionally in black and white. The clay used to be worked by hand. Some tribes incised their pottery with decorations before firing.
The Spanish, especially the [[Jesuit]]s, influenced the technical level of production and the finishing of the native ceramics. These had been characterized by extreme simplicity and production of functional goods. The Jesuits taught the Indian population in the missions.
Ceramic products produced today by some Indian groups include jars, flower vases, and some without specific shapes, as well as water vases. Among those, the pottery most widely sold today due to its beauty and quality comes from Tobaty and Ita.
==By media== ===Baskets weaving=== Baskets are woven from the fibers of canes. Paraguayan Indians weave open baskets, baskets with handles, hand fans, shades, place mats, and especially ''piri'', the typical Paraguayan hat of the country men. Leather products, such as bags, hats, sacks, etc. have their main centers in Limpio and Luque, where also centers for production of beautiful baskets. Materials for [[wickerwork]] include indigenous [[bromeliad]]s including [[tacuarembó]] and [[caraguatá]], as well as [[pindo palm]] leaves.<ref name=para/>
The rich Indian basket production of Paraguay is dividing by plantations. For example, in some communities where the main crop is [[cassava]], baskets are solid with great storage capacity. The ''ajaka mbya'' basket is an average of 35 centimeters diameter with rigid supports that can to hold the heavy weight of the cassavas.
The ''ajak'' is a basket made by weaving ''tacuarembo'' and dark ''guembepi'', making braided figures as well as geometric ones, in accordance with the Guaraní concept of beauty. The baskets associated with the production of corn are smaller and lighter and are constructed from [[Butia|pindo palm tree]] leaves.
===Ceramics=== Ceramics are an ancient art form in Paraguay, and ancient ceramics have been preserved through the centuries. Ceramics range from the utilitarian—cooking vessels, water jugs—to the sacred, such as funerary urns.<ref name=para/>
===Featherwork=== A precolumbian art form, featherwork provides distinctive personal adornment. Brilliantly colored feathers are fashioned into anklets, bracelets, collars, headdresses, and even entire cloaks. [[Guaraní people|Guaraní]] [[medicine men]] used to wear full feather cloaks. The Guaraní create feather [[headdress]]es called ''jeguaka'' worn during ceremonial occasions.<ref name=para/>
===Textile arts=== [[Image:Nanduti lace.jpg|thumb|[[Ñandutí]] lace from [[Asunción]], Paraguay]] Indian embroidery, weaving, and other textile art are an important source of income for the domestic economy. Before the arrival of the Spanish, the Indians used a horizontal piece of material to make hammocks with cotton threads, as well as the baskets and bags to transport food and nets for fishing and hunting.
Later on they also knitted ponchos and other clothing items. As with ceramics, the Jesuits also introduced new techniques in this area, using the vertical frame to make the threads. Tribal artisans began producing sheets, towels, blankets, table clothes and other articles, as well as the special hammocks, which were knitted and still are with cotton threads and ornaments on the sides.
New technical resources brought by the Spanish inspired the typical cotton dresses, the ones called ''ao poi'', made with a fine thread, and the ''povyi'', a little wider thread weaving, as well as linen, and the beautiful ''ñanduti'', which means "spider web" in [[Guaraní language]] and consists of fine embroidery, with which table clothes, curtains, blouses and more are made.
The most coveted textiles are the [[Ñandutí]] embroideries made in the cities of [[Guarambaré]] and [[Itauguá]]. Woven ponchos, known for their beauty and quality, are made by the ethnic groups [[Sanapana|Lengua]], [[Toba (tribe)|Maskoy]], [[Nivaclé]], and [[Wichí]] from the [[Gran Chaco]]. They use sheep wool tinted in red and the ones called of 60 lists, made in [[Pirayú]] and [[Yataity]], in the [[Guairá Department]].
===Rock art=== Ancient indigenous peoples of Paraguay carved [[petroglyph]]s into stone, particularly in the hills of [[Amambay Department]].<ref name=rockart>[http://www.solarmapproject.com/inscriptions/ "The Theme."] ''Solar Map Project." Retrieved 6 Jan 2013.</ref>
===Woodcarving=== Wood is carved into ceremonial masks, smoking pipes, chairs known as ''apyká'', and anthropomorphic and zoomorphic effigies.<ref name=para/> Gourds are also carves with images.
==By tribe== ===Chamacoco=== The [[Chamacoco language|Chamacoco]] ethnic group, from the [[Alto Paraguay Department]], used dresses during their annual ritual called ''Debylyby.'' These are knitted of special fibers. Associated masks are carved from the karaguata tree and adorned with feathers from Chaco birds.
The Chamacocos used a ''pupo'', a protective vest made of karaguata. The ''pupo'' is knitted when the fibers are wet; these become rigid when dry and can serve as armor. They protected the wearer from the arrows of the enemies.
===Karaguata=== The weaving of Karaguata is an important element of the Indian art. It is an expression of the Indian people of the Gran Chaco. The bags of Karaguata are some of the most common applications of fiber twining. Collector's bags are mainly used by women, who carry them on their backs and have a form of a large half moon. Hunting bags are smaller, rectangular, carried by men on their shoulders.
===Paï-Tavytera=== The [[Pai Tavytera people|Pai Tavytera]] from Eastern Paraguay and Brazil are known for their necklaces made from carved wood and colorful seeds of different fruits.<ref>Flowers, Nancy M. [http://www.everyculture.com/South-America/Pa-Tavytera.html Paï-Tavytera.] ''Every Culture.'' (retrieved 29 March 2009)</ref> They use ''urucú'', a red dye made from ''[[Bixa orellana]]'' for [[body painting]]. Personal adornment is made from feathers, such as those of the [[toucan]], and cotton. [[Labret]]s are made from resin. Men typically weave baskets, while women make ceramics.<ref>Flowers, Nancy M. "[http://www.everyculture.com/South-America/Pa-Tavytera.html Paï-Tavytera]." Countries and Their Cultures.</ref> They are also being consulted in interpreting ancient rock art in Amambay.<ref name=rockart/>
===Toba-Qom=== The [[Toba (tribe)|Toba]] tribe makes textiles from colorful wool threads, as well as the traditional bags, ''piri'' hats and [[Trithrinax|carandilla]] leaf baskets. [[Image:Guaranies-artesanias.JPG|thumb|350px|right|Guaraní artisan selling craftwork at a Jesuit Mission]]
===Mbayá=== The [[Mbayá]] Indians have a special ability in making baskets of natural ''tacuara'', that are decorated with drawings of ''Guembepi'' and animals of the zone, as well as their necklaces and wood carving.
===Ayoreo=== The ''ayoreos bagas'' are one of the coveted Indian handiwork. These bags are made with karaguata fibers and exemplify rustic Indian beauty in its conception. The adherence to traditional aesthetics makes them extremely attractive. The [[Ayoreo language|Ayoreo]] also make dishes and spoons of [[Bursera graveolens|Palo Santo]] wood and feather art.
===Maka=== The members of the Maka tribe are excellent weavers. Their traditional blankets, belts, and other elements are knitted with colorful threads.
===Ava Guaraní=== [[Ava Guaraní]] are highly skilled at making baskets and hammocks. They use karaguata fibers, as well as guembepi for baskets that represent a novelty in the Indian work of the country.
==Social context== The art produced by these two ways of living, nomadic and sedentary, reflect the difference of each one. The communities based in the recollection system are nomads. Therefore, their lifestyle allows for a more flexible and open culture, with many adaptations. In the other extreme, the Guaraní agricultural society is very attached to the land and its natural cycles, and naturally presents a conservative tendency, which can be closed to innovations. They distinguish their own from the other's property and have ongoing issues about the need to absorb or reject the foreign influences.<ref>[http://www.fallsworld.com/cultura_guarani.htm Guaraní Culture.] 2008 (retrieved 29 March 2009)</ref>
Despite the differences in these societies and the special characteristics of each one, scholars say that it is possible to establish some shared elements in all Indian communities who live or have lived in Paraguay. Indian art – through its symbols and the free exercise of tribal languages – is one of the most important manifestations of indigenous culture in Paraguay.
==Ceremonies and rituals== [[File:Guarani shaman.JPG|thumb|[[Guaraní people|Guaraní]] [[medicine man|spiritual leader]] with ceremonial gourd rattle and cross, 2006]] Both the collectors and the agricultural societies have as a social nucleus, a mythical body-ritual, from where they can articulate and develop political power, in the judicial order, free time, beauty, and religion.
The mythical [[axis mundi]]-ritual, in essence the Indian cosmology, is composed of communal ceremonies. These are the moments when the community, through songs, dances and rites, show their identity. Indian art finds its first fundamental origins in those ceremonies and in the human body–its principal support. Feathers use in ornamentation, tattoos, and body paintings in the case of the Chaco Indians and the feather art among the Guaraní constitute basic elements of the Indian art in Paraguay.
==Museums== A number of museums are dedicated to showcased indigenous Paraguayan art. These include the [[Guido Boggiani Museum]] in [[San Lorenzo, Paraguay|San Lorenzo]] and in [[Asunción]], the [[Andrés Barbero Ethnographic Museum]],<ref>[http://www.museobarbero.org.py/pagina_nueva_5i.htm "Etnographic Museum Andrés Barbero."] (retrieved 13 July 2011)</ref> the [[Museum of Indigenous Art]],<ref name=para/> and the [[Museo del Barro]] (Museum of Mud).
==See also== {{Portal|Paraguay|Indigenous peoples of the Americas}} * [[Tembetá]] * [[Ticio Escobar]], Paraguayan art critic and curator
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== *Paraguay, Nuestro País, Ediciones Nuevo Mundo. *Turismo Rutas Guia Nº 19.
==External links== *[http://www.indi.gov.py/ Instituto Paraguayo del Indigena] {{es icon}} *[http://www.museodelbarro.org/# Museo del Barro], indigenous art museum in Asunción {{es icon}} *[http://www.senatur.gov.py/index.php?language=2 Paraguay, National Secretary of Tourism] {{en icon}} *[http://www.solarmapproject.com/ Solar Map Project, Amambay, Paraguay], non-profit effort to document Paraguayan rock art {{en icon}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9wG7nFHfa6A&feature=related Chamacoco Indigenous Art from Paraguay], by Fundación Racrdo Migliorisi, YouTube
